('37', 0, 1, 2, 46) 1. PROSTITUTION OF IDEALS
('37', 0, 2, 3, 72) I extract the following from a letter on the remarriage of child widows:
('37', 0, 3, 4, 145) In your reply to B., Agra, in the Young India of September 23, 1 you say that child widows should be remarried by their parents.
('37', 0, 3, 5, 274) How can this be done by those parents who perform kanyadan, i.e., who give their daughters in marriage according to Shastric injunctions?
('37', 0, 3, 6, 412) Surely, it is impossible for parents who have most solemnly and by religious rites renounced all claims on their daughter in favour of their son in law to give her in marriage after his death to another person.
('37', 0, 3, 7, 623) She may of her own accord remarry if she will, but since she was given by her parents as a gift or donation (dan) to her husband, no one in the world after the death of her husband has any right to give her in marriage.
('37', 0, 3, 8, 843) And for the same reason she herself does not possess any right to remarry.
('37', 0, 3, 9, 918) She would, therefore, be faithless and a traitress to her dead husband if she remarried without his express consent given at the time of his death.
('37', 0, 3, 10, 1066) From a logical point of view, it is thus impossible for a widow—be she child, young or old—who was married according to kanyadan system, which is prevalent amongst most sanatanis, to remarry unless her husband had given her permission to do so.
('37', 0, 3, 11, 1311) A true sanatani husband cannot, however, brook the idea of giving such permission.
('37', 0, 3, 12, 1394) He will rather fain agree to his wife’s becoming sati, if she can or, at any rate, will like her to spend the rest of her life in devotion to his memory or, which is the same thing, in devotion to God.
('37', 0, 3, 13, 1596) In this he will solely be actuated by the desire or sense of duty to help the preservation of the high ideals of Hindu marriage and widowhood, which are complementary to and not independent of each other.
('37', 0, 3, 14, 1801) I regard this kind of argument as prostitution of a high ideal.
('37', 0, 3, 15, 1865) No doubt the correspondent means well, but his over anxiety about purity of woman makes him lose sight of elementary justice.
('37', 0, 3, 16, 1991) What is kanyadan in the case of little children?
('37', 0, 3, 17, 2040) Has a father any rights of property over his children?
('37', 0, 3, 18, 2095) He is their protector, not owner.
('37', 0, 3, 19, 2129) And he forfeits the privilege of protection when he abuses it by seeking to barter away the liberty of his ward.
('37', 0, 3, 20, 2242) Again, how can a donation be made to a child who is incapable of receiving a gift?
('37', 0, 3, 21, 2325) There is no gift where the capacity to receive is lacking.
('37', 0, 3, 22, 2384) Surely kanyadan is a mystic, religious rite with a spiritual significance.
('37', 0, 3, 23, 2459) To use such terms in their
('37', 0, 4, 24, 2486) 1Vide “Notes”, 23 9 1926.
('37', 1, 0, 1, 2512) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 1, 1, 2, 2552) literal sense is an abuse of language and religion.
('37', 1, 1, 3, 2604) One may as well take literally the mystic language of the Puranas and believe in the earth being a flat dish sustained on the hood of a thousand headed snake and Divinity lying in soft ease on an ocean of milk for his bed.
('37', 1, 1, 4, 2827) The least that a parent, who has so abused his trust as to give in marriage an infant to an old man in his dotage or to a boy hardly out of his teens, can do is to purge himself of his sin by remarrying the daughter when she becomes widowed.
('37', 1, 1, 5, 3069) As I have said in a previous note 1, such marriages should be declared null and void from the beginning.
('37', 1, 2, 6, 3174) Young India, 11 11 1926
('37', 1, 3, 7, 3198) 2. HANDLOOM V. SPINNING WHEEL
('37', 1, 4, 8, 3228) It seems now to be generally recognized that India, having more than 71 per cent of her population as agriculturists most of whom are idle for nearly six months in the year, needs a supplementary industry and that that industry to be universal can only be hand spinning.
('37', 1, 4, 9, 3499) But some contend that hand weaving is better because it is more remun erative and, therefore, a better proposition.
('37', 1, 4, 10, 3615) Now let us understand this argument in some detail.
('37', 1, 4, 11, 3667) It is said that hand weaving gives about eight annas per day as against one anna from hand spinning.
('37', 1, 4, 12, 3768) Therefore, if a person works for only two hours per day, he will earn from hand weaving two annas against one pice in the same time from hand spinning.
('37', 1, 4, 13, 3920) It is added that one pice would be no economic attraction to anybody and that, if hand weaving could be presented to the people, it would be wrong to ask them to do hand spinning instead.
('37', 1, 4, 14, 4108) The protagonists of the handloom contend further that there is no difficulty about getting as much mill spun yarn as may be required for India’s needs, and, finally, they say that even for the sake of keeping alive hand weaving, which has hitherto defied the competition of weaving mills, it should be pushed with vigour and determination.
('37', 1, 4, 15, 4448) Some of the protagonists of hand weaving even go so far as to say that the hand spinning movement is mischievous in that it turns people’s attention away from the possible industry of hand weaving and misleads them into supporting an impossible industry which has died of its own inherent weakness.
('37', 1, 5, 16, 4747) 1Vide “Defending Child Marriage”, 9 9 1926.
('37', 2, 0, 1, 4791) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 3
('37', 2, 1, 2, 4837) Let us test this specious looking argument.
('37', 2, 1, 3, 4881) In the first instance, hand weaving is not a practicable pro position as a supplementary industry, because it is not easy to teach, it has never been universal in India, it requires several hands to work at, it cannot be done during odd moments.
('37', 2, 1, 4, 5127) It has been and can only be generally an independent occupation and is in the majority of cases the sole occupation like shoe making or smithy.
('37', 2, 1, 5, 5271) Moreover hand weaving cannot be universal in the same sense that hand spinning can be.
('37', 2, 1, 6, 5358) India needs 4,661 million yards of cloth per year.
('37', 2, 1, 7, 5409) A weaver weaves on an average three quarters of a yard per hour of rough khaddar.
('37', 2, 1, 8, 5491) Therefore, if all foreign, indigenous or mill made cloth could be excluded, at the most nine million weavers working at the rate of two hours per day would be required to pro duce the whole of our annual requirements.
('37', 2, 1, 9, 5709) If it be contended that not so many weavers but so many families would be occupied, then the two annas for two hours would have to be distributed among many, thus materially reducing the earnings of the individual per day.
('37', 2, 1, 10, 5932) Now let us consider the possibilities of spinning.
('37', 2, 1, 11, 5983) We know that it was at one time the universal supplementry industry of India.
('37', 2, 1, 12, 6061) Millions have not yet forgotten the art and tens of thousands have even now spinning wheels in their homes.
('37', 2, 1, 13, 6169) Hand spinning is therefore capable of immediate and limitless extension.
('37', 2, 1, 14, 6242) And as it has been found that ten spinners supply one weaver, against nine million weavers ninety million spinners would be able to add to their earnings what to them will be a material and welcome addition, i.e., at least 25 per cent of their income.
('37', 2, 1, 15, 6494) I have assumed the very high figure of 40 rupees per year per head to be the average income.
('37', 2, 1, 16, 6587) Unlike weaving, spinning may be interrupted any moment and, therefore, it can be done during all odd moments.
('37', 2, 1, 17, 6697) Spinning is learnt easily and quickly and the spinner begins to draw some thread from the very commencement.
('37', 2, 1, 18, 6806) Moreover, it is wrong to rely upon an unfailing supply of mill yarn.
('37', 2, 1, 19, 6875) Hand weaving and mill weaving are not complementary pro positions.
('37', 2, 1, 20, 6942) They are mutually antagonistic, the tendency of weaving mills, like all machinery, always being to displace the product of the hand.
('37', 2, 1, 21, 7075) If, therefore, hand weaving could become a supplementary in dustry on a large scale, it would have to be solely dependent on mills which would naturally squeeze the last pie from the weaver for the supply of yarn and would scrap it at the first opportunity.
('37', 3, 0, 1, 7333) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 3, 1, 2, 7373) On the other hand, hand spinning and hand weaving are mutually complementary, as can be today proved from the experience of the existing spinning depots.
('37', 3, 1, 3, 7527) Even as I write, I have letters from co workers saying that in their centres they have to send away weavers for want of yarn.
('37', 3, 1, 4, 7653) It is little known that a vast number of weavers of mill yarn are in the hands of sowcars, and they must be, so long as they rely upon the mill product.
('37', 3, 1, 5, 7806) The village economy demands that the weaver should receive his yarn not from the middleman but from his fellow worker the farmer.
('37', 3, 1, 6, 7936) Again, so far as can be ascertained, there are at present some twenty lakhs of weavers at work.
('37', 3, 1, 7, 8032) Every additional loom means an out lay of at least Rs. 15. Every additional wheel need not mean more than Rs. 3 1/2. The Khadi Pratishthan pattern costs only Rs. 2 1/2. And, at a pinch, even an improvised takli which need not cost anything can be impressed into service.
('37', 3, 1, 8, 8303) Thus, the spinning wheel appears to be the only foundation on which satisfactory village life can be constructed.
('37', 3, 1, 9, 8417) It is the centre round which alone it is possible to build up village reorganization.
('37', 3, 1, 10, 8503) But it is said that one pice per two hours is no economic attraction to even the poor villager.
('37', 3, 1, 11, 8599) In the first place, the wheel is not meant for, it is not now presented to, any person who has a more remunerative employment.
('37', 3, 1, 12, 8726) How is it that thousands of women are today walking a few miles daily or weekly to receive raw cotton and the few pice for the yarn they deliver?
('37', 3, 1, 13, 8872) If a loom were suggested to them, they would not take it up, they would not have the time or the ability for it.
('37', 3, 1, 14, 8985) Town dwellers have no notion of the gnawing poverty of the masses of India.
('37', 3, 1, 15, 9061) Let us not talk of the machine age in their case.
('37', 3, 1, 16, 9111) The machinery of Manchester has robbed them of the butter to their bread which the wheel was, for it has been replaced by nothing else equal to it or better.
('37', 3, 1, 17, 9269) For these, therefore, the spinning wheel is their only hope.
('37', 3, 1, 18, 9330) I do not here examine the more ambitious but chimerical pro posals for agricultural improvements.
('37', 3, 1, 19, 9428) There is room enough for them, I have no doubt.
('37', 3, 1, 20, 9476) But that is a matter of time and education, whereas the ever growing poverty demands an immediate remedy which the wheel alone supplies.
('37', 3, 1, 21, 9613) The wheel does not displace or disregard possi bilities in the shape of such improvements.
('37', 3, 1, 22, 9704) It is a prelude to them.
('37', 3, 1, 23, 9729) Wherever it has gone, it is affecting the lives of villagers in a variety of
('37', 4, 0, 1, 9806) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 5
('37', 4, 1, 2, 9852) ways and it enables the townspeople to establish a living contct with the villagers and their villages.
('37', 4, 1, 3, 9956) “If hand spinning is all you say, how is it that it has not already been universally adopted?”, asks the critic.
('37', 4, 1, 4, 10069) The question is quite fair.
('37', 4, 1, 5, 10097) The answer is simple.
('37', 4, 1, 6, 10119) The message of the wheel has to be carried to a people who have no hope, no initiative left in them and who would, if left to themselves, starve and die rather than work and live.
('37', 4, 1, 7, 10299) Such was not the case before, but long neglect has made laziness a habit with them.
('37', 4, 1, 8, 10383) That laziness can only be removed by the living contact and example of men of character and industry plying the wheel before them and by gently showing them the way.
('37', 4, 1, 9, 10549) The second great diffi culty is the absence of a ready market for khaddar.
('37', 4, 1, 10, 10624) I confess that it cannot for the time being compete with mill cloth.
('37', 4, 1, 11, 10693) I will not engage in any such killing competition.
('37', 4, 1, 12, 10744) The capitalist may for capturing the market sell his calico for nothing.
('37', 4, 1, 13, 10817) The manufacturer whose only capital is labour cannot afford to do so.
('37', 4, 1, 14, 10887) Can there be any competition between the dead artificial rose, however symmetrical it may be, and the living rose whose two petals will not be alike, or can there be any competition between a wax statue of Cromwell and the living one?
('37', 4, 1, 15, 11122) Khaddar is a living thing.
('37', 4, 1, 16, 11149) But India has lost her eye for the real art and is, therefore, satisfied with the glossy exterior, Revive the healthy national taste for khaddar and you will find every village a busy hive.
('37', 4, 1, 17, 11339) As it is, the resouces of khaddar organizations are taxed to the utmost in order to create a market for the article.
('37', 4, 1, 18, 11456) The marvel is that in spite of heavy odds against it, the movement is making headway.
('37', 4, 1, 19, 11542) Over twelve lacs worth of khaddar was sold only last year.
('37', 4, 1, 20, 11601) But it is nothing to boast of when one thinks of what needs to be done.
('37', 4, 1, 21, 11673) I have thus summarized the case for the spinning wheel as a supplementary industry as against the handloom.
('37', 4, 1, 22, 11781) Let there be no con fusion of thought.
('37', 4, 1, 23, 11820) I am not against the handloom.
('37', 4, 1, 24, 11851) It is a great and thriving cottage industry.
('37', 4, 1, 25, 11896) It will progress automatically if the spin ning wheel succeeds.
('37', 4, 1, 26, 11960) It is bound to die if the wheel fails.
('37', 4, 1, 27, 11999) I invite criticism of the argument and shall gladly retrace my steps if the argument or the facts cannot be sustained.
('37', 4, 1, 28, 12118) Young India, 11 11 1926
('37', 5, 0, 1, 12142) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 5, 1, 2, 12182) 3. COW PROTECTION
('37', 5, 2, 3, 12200) A correspondent writes:
('37', 5, 3, 4, 12224) As most of the Hindus intuitively feel that the cow should be protected at all events, I too do so.
('37', 5, 3, 5, 12324) I had witnessed the miserable sight of starving cows in their prime of life, being sold in lots, to Mussalman hide merchants in the famine stricken areas of the Ceded Districts.
('37', 5, 4, 6, 12502) The Hindu scriptures alone seem to have enjoined cow protection on its followers.
('37', 5, 4, 7, 12584) I have been trying to understand the philosophy of it.
('37', 5, 4, 8, 12639) If the cow has to be protected purely from selfish motives, on account of its continuous utility from its birth till after its death, cow protection should have become universal and not confined to Hindus alone, for, mankind by instinct is selfish.
('37', 5, 4, 9, 12888) If, on the other hand, it has to be protected on account of its meek and harmless nature, there are other animals as the sheep and deer which also equally require human protection.
('37', 5, 4, 10, 13069) What then is the special virtue in the cow, exclusively known or useful to the Hindu, over other domestic animals at any rate?
('37', 5, 4, 11, 13196) If Hindus, not excluding the vegetarian and orthodox sections, are entitled to kill buffaloes, goats, sheep, etc., for purposes of food or sacrifice, what right have we to resent Mussalmans killing the cow for sacrifice or food?
('37', 5, 4, 12, 13425) Would not the appeal of the Hindus to the Mussalmans to protect the cow be more reasonable and effective, if we Hindus ourselves gave up animal killing for food or sacrifice?
('37', 5, 4, 13, 13600) There is much to be said in favour of the argument adopted by the correspondent.
('37', 5, 4, 14, 13681) But man does not govern himself by logic.
('37', 5, 4, 15, 13723) He is a complex being; therefore, a multiplicity of considerations act upon him and move him to do or to refrain from doing things.
('37', 5, 4, 16, 13855) Logically speaking, therefore, a Hindu who protects the cow should protect every animal.
('37', 5, 4, 17, 13944) But taking all things into consideration, we may not cavil at his protecting the cow because he fails to protect the other animals.
('37', 5, 4, 18, 14076) The only question, therefore, to consider is whether he is right in protecting the cow.
('37', 5, 4, 19, 14164) And he cannot be wrong in so doing if non killing of animals generally may be regarded as a duty for one who believes in ahimsa.
('37', 5, 4, 20, 14293) And every Hindu, and for that matter every man of religion, does so.
('37', 5, 4, 21, 14362) The duty of not killing animals generally and, therefore, protecting them must be accepted as an indisputable fact.
('37', 5, 4, 22, 14478) It is then so much to the credit of Hinduism that it has taken up cow protection as a duty.
('37', 5, 4, 23, 14570) And he is a poor specimen of Hinduism who stops merely at cow protection when he can extend the arm of protection to other animals.
('37', 5, 4, 24, 14702) The cow merely stands as a symbol, and protection of the cow is the least he is expected to undertake.
('37', 5, 4, 25, 14805) But, as I
('37', 6, 0, 1, 14815) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 7
('37', 6, 1, 2, 14861) have shown already in my previous writings, he is failing even in this elementary obligation.
('37', 6, 1, 3, 14955) The motive that actuates cow protection is not ‘purely selfish’, though selfish consideration undoubtedly enters into it.
('37', 6, 1, 4, 15077) If it was purely selfish, the cow would be killed as in other countries after it had ceased to give full use.
('37', 6, 1, 5, 15187) The Hindus will not kill the cow even though she may be a heavy burden.
('37', 6, 1, 6, 15259) The numberless goshalas that have been established by charitably minded people for tending disa bled and useless cows is in a way an eloquent testimony of the effort that is being made in the direction.
('37', 6, 1, 7, 15462) Though they are today very poor institutions for the object to be achieved, the fact does not detract from the value of the motive behind the act.
('37', 6, 1, 8, 15609) The philosophy of cow protection therefore is, in my opinion, sublime.
('37', 6, 1, 9, 15680) It immediately puts the animal creation on the same level with man so far as the right to live is concerned.
('37', 6, 1, 10, 15789) But it is no part of Hinduism to prevent by force cow slaughter by those who do not believe in cow protection.
('37', 6, 1, 11, 15900) Hindus will bring the Mussalmans and the rest of the world to their way of thinking only by living the religion of ahimsa as fully as it is humanly possible.
('37', 6, 1, 12, 16058) They must rely upon the working of the great principle in their own lives and making its effective appeal to the outer world.
('37', 6, 1, 13, 16184) They will not convert the latter by force of arms.
('37', 6, 1, 14, 16235) They certainly can by force of ahimsa.
('37', 6, 1, 15, 16274) We little realize the matchless potency of ahimsa when it is thoroughly put into active operation.
('37', 6, 1, 16, 16373) Young India, 11 11 1926
('37', 6, 2, 17, 16397) 4. TAKLI IN SCHOOLS
('37', 6, 3, 18, 16417) Dr. Profulla Chandra Ghosh of Khadi Pratishthan sends me the following notes on the introduction of takli in schools: 1
('37', 6, 4, 19, 16537) I congratulate the authorities in charge of the Malikanda national school.
('37', 6, 4, 20, 16612) A spinning wheel is any day superior to the takli for obtaining a larger quantity of yarn.
('37', 6, 4, 21, 16703) And I have never intended to give absolute preference to the takli over the wheel.
('37', 6, 4, 22, 16786) But I have little doubt
('37', 6, 5, 23, 16810) 1 Not reproduced here.
('37', 6, 5, 24, 16833) The correspondent had argued, giving figures about the progress in spinning on the charkha by boys of the national school at Malikanda, Dacca, that it could not be said that takli was always to be preferred to the charkha in schools.
('37', 6, 5, 25, 17067) That could be done only in the case of the younger boys who could not ply the charkha.
('37', 7, 0, 1, 17154) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 7, 1, 2, 17194) in my mind that, in the large number of schools we have, the takli yields better results than the spinning wheel as has been amply shown by general experience.
('37', 7, 1, 3, 17354) The reasons are obvious.
('37', 7, 1, 4, 17379) School rooms are too small to accommodate the spinning wheels for all the boys and girls.
('37', 7, 1, 5, 17469) Secondly, even if room could be found, they are far too expensive compared to the takli.
('37', 7, 1, 6, 17558) Thirdly, the wheel frequently goes out of order and neither the school masters nor the pupils are able to set them right in a moment.
('37', 7, 1, 7, 17692) Once the wheel goes out of order, it often takes a long time to repair it.
('37', 7, 1, 8, 17767) It is not possible to supervise the work of a large number of boys spinning at the wheel.
('37', 7, 1, 9, 17857) On the other hand, the takli is incredibly cheap.
('37', 7, 1, 10, 17907) It can be worked by thousands at a time.
('37', 7, 1, 11, 17948) It can be handled even in a crowded room requiring practically no space for its accommodation.
('37', 7, 1, 12, 18043) It rarely goes out of order and when it does, it can be instantaneously replaced.
('37', 7, 1, 13, 18125) Takli spinning can be supervised no matter how many pupils engage in the operation.
('37', 7, 1, 14, 18209) The quantitative result of mass spinning on the takli is on the whole more satisfactory than on the wheel.
('37', 7, 1, 15, 18316) But having said all this in praise of the takli, needless to say I can have no objection to any school taking up the wheel in preference to the takli if it can overcome the objections men tioned by me.
('37', 7, 1, 16, 18518) Young India, 11 11 1926
('37', 7, 2, 17, 18542) 5. NOTES
('37', 7, 3, 18, 18551) KHADDAR AND GOVERNMENT SERVANTS A correspondent says:
('37', 7, 4, 19, 18605) Some of the Government servants are terribly afraid to purchase hand spun and hand woven cloth when our hawkers approach them.
('37', 7, 4, 20, 18732) They are under the impression that they should not purchase khaddar, yet the Bombay Government is openly appealing to the people to encourage Indian industries.
('37', 7, 4, 21, 18893) Can you say whether the Madras Government servants are allowed to purchase hand spun and hand woven cloth without fear of the Government?
('37', 7, 4, 22, 19031) I wish I could answer the question.
('37', 7, 4, 23, 19067) But I have not the power.
('37', 7, 4, 24, 19093) It is however inconceivable to me that any Government should proscribe the use of hand spun and hand woven cloth.
('37', 7, 4, 25, 19207) It is possible to conceive the insistence on a form of dress, but certainly not the kind of cloth to be used.
('37', 7, 4, 26, 19317) It is painful to find that there are Government servants who labour under imaginary fears.
('37', 7, 4, 27, 19408) I have seen many Government servants making free use of khaddar without let or hindrance.
('37', 7, 4, 28, 19498) If I was a servant
('37', 8, 0, 1, 19517) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 9
('37', 8, 1, 2, 19563) of the Madras Government, I should unhesitatingly wear khaddar un less there was positive prohibition to the contrary in which case I should resign.

('37', 8, 7, 16, 21486) There was another resolution passed by the Dal inviting me to visit the Province next year during the sale days.

('37', 8, 7, 18, 21730) The members should know that I put a fairly high price on my presence.
('37', 8, 7, 19, 21801) They will have to put before me a more attractive programme than they have prepared if they are to draw me.

('37', 9, 1, 3, 22022) And as I do not believe in polyandry, the winner will have to offer a tempting dowry.
('37', 9, 1, 4, 22108) It would be well for them therefore not to build any hope on my going to Karnatak early next year.
('37', 9, 2, 5, 22207) KHADI AMONGST NON BRAHMINS
('37', 9, 3, 6, 22234) A correspondent writes:
('37', 9, 4, 7, 22258) You will be glad to learn that the non Brahmins of Nipani are taking a keen interest in khadi.
('37', 9, 4, 8, 22353) It is the one platform on which Brahmins and non Brahmins are uniting.
('37', 9, 4, 9, 22424) There was a large meeting on the 23rd of October.
('37', 9, 4, 10, 22474) It was a good meeting.
('37', 9, 4, 11, 22497) Mr. Rawan was present at the meeting and he gave his whole hearted support to khadi although he said that he continued to abide by the non Brahmin party’s programme of work.
('37', 9, 4, 12, 22671) A khadi bhandar was opened at Nipani.
('37', 9, 4, 13, 22709) This was chiefly due to the exertion of Sheth Mulji Sicca of Cutch.
('37', 9, 4, 14, 22777) He has promised to sell khaddar at cost price.
('37', 9, 4, 15, 22824) The non Brahmin friends seem to be convinced that the question of growing poverty of the masses, which term includes non Brahmins, cannot be solved without the universal use of khadi.
('37', 9, 4, 16, 23008) The Nipani leaders therefore feel that it is not enough to be hostile to khadi but it is necessary to encourage khadi by all available means.
('37', 9, 4, 17, 23150) I congratulate the non Brahmin friends of Nipani upon their decision, and hope that they will organize khadi work so as to place it on a stable basis.
('37', 9, 5, 18, 23301) SPINNING IN SCHOOLS
('37', 9, 6, 19, 23321) The following report about the progress of spinning in the schools under Guntur Municipality will be read with interest:
('37', 9, 7, 20, 23442) The number of schools is 35.
('37', 9, 8, 21, 23471) Girls’ schools 9 and boys’ schools 26. There are 454 girls and 363 boys.
('37', 9, 8, 22, 23544) The number of girls spinning is 70 and that of boys 60. 15 charkhas are supplied to the boys’ schools and 17 to the girls’ schools.
('37', 9, 8, 23, 23676) During the year the boys have spun 24,000 yds.
('37', 9, 8, 24, 23723) and the girls 26,000 yds.
('37', 9, 8, 25, 23749) The boys’ yarn weighs 118 tolas and the girls’ yarn 130 tolas.
('37', 9, 8, 26, 23812) The Municipality purchased 3 maunds of slivers for Rs. 46 8 0. The yarn is in the Municipal office.
('37', 9, 8, 27, 23912) About 100 of the pupils wear khadi.
('37', 9, 8, 28, 23948) The number of all the teachers is 87. Out of them 30 are women and 57 are men.
('37', 9, 8, 29, 24027) Almost all wear khadi.
('37', 9, 8, 30, 24050) 63 give yarn to the A.I.S.A. One is also a Congress member under the yarn subscription rule.
('37', 9, 9, 31, 24143) Rs. 500 worth of khadi was purchased.

('37', 10, 6, 12, 24942) SPINNING DURING THE WAR
('37', 10, 7, 13, 24966) A Mombasa correspondent sends the following extracts from My Reminiscences of East Africa by General Von Kettow Vorbeck, showing the possibilities of spinning under stress:
('37', 10, 8, 14, 25139) Notwithstanding the great amount of booty taken at Tanga, it was evident that, as the war seemed likely to be prolonged, the stocks in the Colony would become exhausted.
('37', 10, 8, 15, 25309) The natives at New Moschi began all of a sudden to wear silk; this was by no means a sign of special extravagance; the stocks of cotton clothing in the Indian shops were simply coming to an end.
('37', 10, 8, 16, 25504) We had seriously to think of starting manufactures ourselves, in order to convert the abundant raw material into finished products.
('37', 10, 8, 17, 25636) A curious existence now developed, reminding one of the industry of the Swiss family Robinson.
('37', 10, 8, 18, 25731) Cotton fields existed in plenty.
('37', 10, 8, 19, 25764) Popular books were hunted up, giving information about the forgotten arts of hand spinning and weaving; white and black women took to spinning by hand; at the missions and in private workshops spinning wheels and looms were built.
('37', 10, 8, 20, 25995) In this manner, in a short time, the first useful piece of cotton cloth was produced.
('37', 10, 8, 21, 26081) After various trials, the most suitable dye was obtained from the root of a tree called Ndaa, which imparted a brownish yellow colour, very inconspicuous both in the grass and in the bush, and therefore, specially suitable for uniforms.
('37', 10, 8, 22, 26318) Would that we considered India to be in a state of war and refrained from using foreign cloth and even Indian mill made cloth.
('37', 10, 8, 23, 26445) All argument against the possibility of hand spinning will then vanish like smoke.
('37', 10, 8, 24, 26528) And are we not in a state worse than war when we have proof positive that millions of the inhabitants of India are living in semi starvation?

('37', 11, 1, 2, 26711) “ALL FOR THEE”
('37', 11, 2, 3, 26726) A kind Tamil friend sends me for my day of silence quotations that do one’s soul good to read.
('37', 11, 2, 4, 26821) I do not give in Young India quotations except when there is an association about them and when they are relevant.
('37', 11, 2, 5, 26936) In the collection the friend has sent me I find the following very appropriate verses from George Herbert:
('37', 11, 3, 6, 27043) Teach me, my God and King,
('37', 11, 4, 7, 27070) In all things Thee to see,
('37', 11, 5, 8, 27097) And what I do in anything,
('37', 11, 6, 9, 27124) To do it as for Thee.
('37', 11, 7, 10, 27146) A servant with this clause
('37', 11, 8, 11, 27173) Makes drudgerie divine;
('37', 11, 9, 12, 27197) Who sweeps a room as for Thy laws,
('37', 11, 10, 13, 27232) Makes that and the action fine.
('37', 11, 11, 14, 27264) I give one more equally appropriate.
('37', 11, 11, 15, 27301) It is from Ruskin:
('37', 11, 12, 16, 27320) When we build, let it be such a work as our descendants will thank us for; and let us think, as we lay stone on stone, that a time is to come when stones will be held sacred because our hands have touched them, and that men will say as they look upon them: See!
('37', 11, 12, 17, 27582) this our fathers did for us.
('37', 11, 12, 18, 27611) Public life would be much purer than it is if we would do everything in the name of the King of kings and not for self but for posterity.

('37', 19, 0, 1, 37453) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 19, 1, 2, 37494) 20. IS THIS HUMANITY?—VI
('37', 19, 2, 3, 37519) [November 14, 1926] A friend has sent a long letter containing a number of questions and raising a number of dificulties.
('37', 19, 2, 4, 37641) He has also sent me his copies of Navajivan with profuse marginal notes on this series of articles.
('37', 19, 2, 5, 37741) Some of his questions have been already answered in these pages.
('37', 19, 2, 6, 37806) Without reproducing here the rest of his questions, I propose merely to give my answers.
('37', 19, 2, 7, 37895) I think I have been considering the whole question quite dispassionately.
('37', 19, 2, 8, 37969) I do not think I could be accused of any partiality for himsa or for my own peculiar views in the matter.
('37', 19, 2, 9, 38075) My partiality is all for truth which I seek to find out through ahimsa.
('37', 19, 2, 10, 38147) It is my conviction that it cannot be found out in any other way.
('37', 19, 2, 11, 38213) The question in dispute for me is not whether truth is our goal or not, nor whether ahimsa is or is not the only way to it.
('37', 19, 2, 12, 38337) There is no possibility of my ever doubting these fundamental principles.
('37', 19, 2, 13, 38411) The question before me is about the practice of these principles.
('37', 19, 2, 14, 38477) Every day I see fresh aspects opening out to me.
('37', 19, 2, 15, 38526) There is every possibility of my making mistakes in the practice of ahimsa and, though I am taking every precaution possible to avoid them, it is possible that I may err occasionally.
('37', 19, 2, 16, 38710) Let not friends, therefore, impute partiality to me when I cannot agree with them.
('37', 19, 2, 17, 38793) Letthem believe me to be unconsciously in error and bear with me.
('37', 19, 2, 18, 38859) I now proceed to give the answers.
('37', 19, 2, 19, 38894) 1. The question to solve is not what is hydrophobia and how to treat it.
('37', 19, 2, 20, 38967) 2 The municipality or the Government will find a remedy not in accordance with ahimsa but with what they conceive to be public interest.
('37', 19, 2, 21, 39104) The Mahajan can find the right remedy if they are truly non violent.
('37', 19, 2, 22, 39173) Government will never subscribe to the absolute principle of non destruction of animals (dogs in the present case).
('37', 19, 2, 23, 39289) Municipa lities have members belonging to different faiths and different comm unities.
('37', 19, 2, 24, 39376) They cannot, therefore, be expected to insist on a non violent remedy.
('37', 19, 2, 25, 39447) 3. The duty of finding a non violent remedy is the Mahajan’s.
('37', 19, 2, 26, 39509) It is a mistake to think that the Mahajan is blameless or helpless.
('37', 19, 2, 27, 39577) 4. For the purpose of the discussion, I make no distincition between a rabid dog and a man who has run amuck and is in the act of dealing death.
('37', 19, 2, 28, 39722) Habitual violence is a disease.
('37', 19, 2, 29, 39754) The habitually violent man goes on in his murderous career only because he is beside
('37', 20, 0, 1, 39839) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 21
('37', 20, 1, 2, 39886) himself.
('37', 20, 1, 3, 39895) Both a rabid dog and a rabid man are worthy of pity.
('37', 20, 1, 4, 39948) When they are found in the act of injuring others, and when there is no other remedy than to take their life, it becomes a duty to do so to arrest their activity.
('37', 20, 1, 5, 40111) The duty is all the greater in case of a votary of ahimsa.
('37', 20, 1, 6, 40170) 5. I have never meant that everyone should own a dog.
('37', 20, 1, 7, 40224) What I have said is that the dogs should in no case be ownerless.
('37', 20, 1, 8, 40290) Not that the owned dogs will be immune, but the owners will be responsible for them if they are diseased or get rabies.
('37', 20, 1, 9, 40410) 6. The ownerless stray dogs are not innocent as lambs.
('37', 20, 1, 10, 40465) They were never so.
('37', 20, 1, 11, 40485) Owned dogs are generally so.
('37', 20, 1, 12, 40514) The purpose of the present controversy is to make all the dogs innocuous.
('37', 20, 1, 13, 40588) 7. I have never suggested that roving dogs should be killed wherever found.
('37', 20, 1, 14, 40664) I have suggested enabling legislation in the interest of the dogs themselves.
('37', 20, 1, 15, 40742) That will make humanly inclined people alive to their sense of duty and they will then either own dogs or find out some other remedy and thus make the existence of stray dogs im possible.
('37', 20, 1, 16, 40930) In refusing alms to the beggar, the purpose is not to starve him, but to teach him self help, to make him a man.
('37', 20, 1, 17, 41043) The duty of killing dogs arises in the circumstances and to the extent I have indic ated in the previous articles.
('37', 20, 1, 18, 41158) To say that it is a sin to extirpate dogs is not to contradict me.
('37', 20, 1, 19, 41225) For I have never expressed a contrary opinion.
('37', 20, 1, 20, 41272) 8. It is idle to discuss whether Mr. Ambalal’s conduct was or was not proper, or whether my opinion about it was or was not correct.
('37', 20, 1, 21, 41405) The public is not in full possession of the details of the incident.
('37', 20, 1, 22, 41474) The broader question of ahimsa is the main issue, and to bring in Mr. Ambalal in the discussion is to cloud the issue.
('37', 20, 1, 23, 41593) 9. The issue is: Whether, in consonance with the principle of ahimsa, it may be a duty to kill certain dogs under certain circum stances when no other alternative is possible.
('37', 20, 1, 24, 41769) I submit that it may be and I hold that there cannot be two opinions in the matter.
('37', 20, 1, 25, 41853) There may be a difference as to whether particular circumstances justify the act.
('37', 20, 1, 26, 41935) The consolation for a votary of ahimsa lies in the fact that, from his standpoint, such circumstances can only be rare.
('37', 20, 1, 27, 42055) 10. But I can see one difference of opinion that must for the time being remain.
('37', 20, 1, 28, 42136) In the letter under consideration as also in many others, I see that there is an instinctive horror of killing living beings under any circumstances whatsoever.
('37', 20, 1, 29, 42297) For instance, an alternative has been suggested in the shape of confining even rabid dogs in a certain place and allowing them to die a slow death.
('37', 20, 1, 30, 42445) Now, my idea of com 
('37', 21, 0, 1, 42466) 22 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 21, 1, 2, 42507) passion makes this thing impossible for me.
('37', 21, 1, 3, 42551) I cannot for a moment bear to see a dog, or for that matter any other living being, helplessly suffering the torture of a slow death.
('37', 21, 1, 4, 42685) I do not kill a human being thus circumstanced because I have more hopeful remedies.
('37', 21, 1, 5, 42770) I should kill a dog similarly situated, because in its case I am without a remedy.
('37', 21, 1, 6, 42853) Should my child be attacked by rabies and there was no hopeful remedy to relieve his agony, I should consider it my duty to take his life.
('37', 21, 1, 7, 42992) Fatalism has its limits.
('37', 21, 1, 8, 43017) We leave things to Fate after exhausting all the remedies.
('37', 21, 1, 9, 43076) One of the remedies, and the final one to relieve the agony of a tortured child, is to take his life.
('37', 21, 1, 10, 43178) But I shall not labour this point.
('37', 21, 1, 11, 43213) What to my mind is impotence of the votaries of ahimsa is an obstacle to a true understanding of this dharma.
('37', 21, 1, 12, 43323) I hope therefore that those who differ from me will for the present bear with me.
('37', 21, 1, 13, 43405) So much about the thoughful letter of a friend.
('37', 21, 1, 14, 43453) I shall now deal with an angry letter.
('37', 21, 1, 15, 43492) The letter says:
('37', 21, 2, 16, 43509) You have been so much under the Western influence that you have learnt to think it proper to kill lower beings for the sake of man.
('37', 21, 2, 17, 43641) It is better for you to confess your error and apologize to the world.
('37', 21, 2, 18, 43712) You should have made up your mind in this matter after exhaustless [sic] sifting.
('37', 21, 2, 19, 43794) Instead, you have passionately taken sides and discredited yourself.
('37', 21, 2, 20, 43863) This is the least offensive sentence I have picked up from letters of this type.
('37', 21, 2, 21, 43944) I submit I have not formed my opinion without much deliberation.
('37', 21, 2, 22, 44009) It is not an opinion I have recently formed.
('37', 21, 2, 23, 44054) Neither is ithasty.
('37', 21, 2, 24, 44074) One should not let one’s so called greatness come in the way of the formation of opinion, otherwise one cannot arrive at truth.
('37', 21, 2, 25, 44202) I do not think that everything Western is to be rejected.
('37', 21, 2, 26, 44260) I have condemned the Western civilization in no measured terms.
('37', 21, 2, 27, 44324) I still do so, but it does not mean that everything Western should be rejected.
('37', 21, 2, 28, 44404) I have learnt a great deal from the West and I am grateful to it.
('37', 21, 2, 29, 44470) I should think myself unfortunate if contact with and the literature of the West had no influence on me.
('37', 21, 2, 30, 44575) But I do not think I owe my opinion about the dogs to my Western education or Western influence.
('37', 21, 2, 31, 44672) The West (with the exception of a small school of thought) thinks that it is no sin to kill the lower animals for what it regards to be the benefit of man.
('37', 21, 2, 32, 44828) It has, therefore, encouraged vivisection.
('37', 21, 2, 33, 44871) The West does not think it wrong to commit violence of all kinds for the satisfaction of the palate.
('37', 21, 2, 34, 44972) I do not subscribe to these views.
('37', 21, 2, 35, 45007) According to the Western standard, it is no sin, on the contrary it is a merit to kill animals that are no longer useful.
('37', 21, 2, 36, 45129) Whereas I recognize limits at every step.
('37', 21, 2, 37, 45171) I regard
('37', 22, 0, 1, 45180) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 23
('37', 22, 1, 2, 45227) even the destruction of vegetable life as himsa.
('37', 22, 1, 3, 45276) It is not the teaching of the West.
('37', 22, 1, 4, 45312) Argumentum ad hominem has no place in a discussion of principles and their practice.
('37', 22, 1, 5, 45397) My opinions should be considered as they are, irrespective of whether they are derived from the West or the East.
('37', 22, 1, 6, 45511) Whether they are based on truth or untruth, himsa or ahimsa, is the only thing to be considred.
('37', 22, 1, 7, 45607) I firmly believe that they are based on truth and ahimsa.
('37', 22, 1, 8, 45665) Young India, 18 11 1926
('37', 22, 2, 9, 45689) 21. VAUTHA FAIR
('37', 22, 3, 10, 45705) Fairs are held all over our country.
('37', 22, 3, 11, 45742) At some place or other annual fairs are held.
('37', 22, 3, 12, 45788) All sorts of people come to these fairs from nearby places.
('37', 22, 3, 13, 45848) For the big fairs people come from every part of India.
('37', 22, 3, 14, 45904) Such a fair is held every Kartiki Purnima at Vautha in Dholka taluka.
('37', 22, 3, 15, 45974) On behalf of the District Congress Committee, Shri Dahyabhai has been rendering service there, with the help of a small band of volunteers, for the last several years.
('37', 22, 3, 16, 46142) This year, too, he has published an appeal for volunteers.
('37', 22, 3, 17, 46201) Last year and the year before I had intended to attend this fair but could not.
('37', 22, 3, 18, 46281) This year, too, to my great regret, I am not able to go.
('37', 22, 3, 19, 46338) But I recommend that those who wish to do social service should go there.
('37', 22, 3, 20, 46412) Even in the fairs organized for religious purposes, evil prctices have grown rampant.
('37', 22, 3, 21, 46498) Cheats go to such fairs and deceive simple people.
('37', 22, 3, 22, 46549) Many kinds of immorality are practised there and gambling and other vices encouraged.
('37', 22, 3, 23, 46635) Volunteers can definitely effect some reform by going there.
('37', 22, 3, 24, 46696) I hope that those who can spare some days will go there and render all possible services.

('37', 27, 7, 9, 52717) 31. INTRODUCTION TO “HAND SPINNING AND HAND WEAVING ”
('37', 27, 8, 10, 52771) SABARMATI, November 16, 1926 It will be remembered that early last year Sjt.
('37', 27, 8, 11, 52848) Revashanker Jagjivan Mehta, the Joint Treasurer of the National Congress, announced a prize of Rs. 1,000 for the best essay on spinning.
('37', 27, 8, 12, 52985) The judges appointed were Sjts.
('37', 27, 8, 13, 53017) Ambalal Sarabhai, Shankerlal Banker, Maganlal Gandhi and myself.
('37', 27, 8, 14, 53082) Sixty other essays were received.
('37', 27, 8, 15, 53116) After much deliberation, the judges decided to distribute the prize between Professor S. V. Puntambekar, at present of the Benares Hindu Univer sity, and Sjt.
('37', 27, 8, 16, 53275) N. S. Varadachari.
('37', 27, 8, 17, 53294) The essay that is now being presented to the public is the result of the joint effort of these two winners who were requested to amalgamate their essays and give a joint production.
('37', 27, 8, 18, 53476) It is difficult to say how far the effort is an improvement upon the originals.
('37', 27, 8, 19, 53556) But workers in the vast field of hand spinning will find ample material in the following pages to strengthen their position and I should be much surprised if the sceptic does not find enough food for reflection.
('37', 27, 8, 20, 53768) The authors have applied themselves to an examination prin cipally of the following propositions: Are there millions in India who require a supplementary occu pation, the majority being idle for want of it during at least four months in the year?
('37', 27, 8, 21, 54015) Is hand spinning the only supplementary occu 
('37', 27, 9, 22, 54061) 1 This was sent in reply to a telegram dated November 15 reading: “Kindly wire whom you prefer Birla or Sriprakasa.
('37', 27, 9, 23, 54177) Congress work suffering.”
('37', 28, 0, 1, 54203) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 29
('37', 28, 1, 2, 54250) pation and, if it is, can it be easily taken up by the people?
('37', 28, 1, 3, 54313) Is it possi ble to sell khaddar woven from hand spun yarn among the people in the teeth of the competition offered by foreign and Indian mills?
('37', 28, 1, 4, 54457) The readers will find that the authors have endeavoured to give an affirmative answer to all these important questions.
('37', 28, 1, 5, 54577) Is it not the duty of everyone who wants to see an amelioration in the condition of India’s masses carefully to read what the authors have stated and to support the khaddar movement if they accept their conclusions?
('37', 28, 1, 6, 54793) Let them denounce it as a waste of effort, if they can dare controvert the facts adduced by the authors.

('37', 30, 2, 3, 57003) [Before November 18, 1926] 1
('37', 30, 3, 4, 57032) CHHAGANLAL, It will not do if you remain lenient.

('37', 34, 5, 19, 67396) 40. SOUTH AFRICAN SITUATION
('37', 34, 6, 20, 67424) Here are extracts from a letter from Mr. Andrews after his arrival in Durban;
('37', 34, 7, 21, 67502) It is good to get here again, and though it has been a difficult time on the voyage, I am so thankful that I came on and did not delay longer.
('37', 34, 7, 22, 67645) There are any amount of things here to be settled and other things to put straight before the delegation arrives, and it will take every moment of my time to get through.
('37', 34, 8, 23, 67816) Today I have had the warmest possible welcome and Rawat’s Bioscope was crowded this evening at the ‘welcome’.
('37', 34, 8, 24, 67926) I am staying with Sorabji at 19, 1st Avenue.
('37', 34, 8, 25, 67971) The house at 110, Field Street, is all pulled down and the site sold
('37', 35, 0, 1, 68040) 36 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 35, 1, 2, 68081) to Europeans!
('37', 35, 2, 3, 68095) The days have been crowded to the full and it is almost impossible to avoid it as I had expected.
('37', 35, 2, 4, 68193) There was a very serious smallpox outbreak in the Indian quarters and every single smallpox case was that of an Indian.
('37', 35, 2, 5, 68313) The mortality was as high as 25% and it was of a very virulent type.
('37', 35, 2, 6, 68382) There were vicious letters in the Press abusing Indians for insanitary habits, etc.
('37', 35, 2, 7, 68466) The one thing to do was what you did in Johannesburg and after getting vaccinated myself (without which I could have done nothing at all), I got the Medical Officer to let me visit the Indians who were kept in quarantine daily, and did everything I could to pacify them.
('37', 35, 2, 8, 68737) Also we met and formed an Indian Health Committee and decided to work under the doctor’s orders and he has already set us to work.
('37', 35, 2, 9, 68868) At once, as soon as this was announced the whole tone of the Press changed and we have been praised where before we were being blamed.
('37', 35, 2, 10, 69003) Altogether it is going to work out for the best.

('37', 35, 3, 13, 69333) It has been rather difficult to persuade them not to have a big demonstration just at the time of the Conference, thinking it would ‘impress’ them.

('37', 36, 4, 19, 72639) 42 CONDITIONS OF PACIFIC STRIKES
('37', 36, 5, 20, 72672) A friend sends me an extract from No More War, an organ of the British Pacifists.
('37', 36, 5, 21, 72754) I copy from the extract the following conditions Mr. A. Fenner Brockway lays down as a test of a pacific strike:
('37', 36, 6, 22, 72867) 1. A strike in protest of social evils which destroy human life can be as much an act of pacifism as a strike against war.
('37', 36, 6, 23, 72990) (Starvation wages kill as many
('37', 37, 0, 1, 73021) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 37, 1, 2, 73062) human beings as are killed by guns.)
('37', 37, 2, 3, 73099) 2. If it be said that “constitutional” means could be used to end these evils, the same can be said of war.
('37', 37, 2, 4, 73207) Our “constitutional” machinery is inadequate.
('37', 37, 2, 5, 73253) The voters two years ago had neither wage reductions nor war in mind.
('37', 37, 3, 6, 73323) 3.If it be said that a strike (and particularly a general strike) against wage reductions is an effort to “coerce” the nation or the Government, the same can be said about a general strike against war.
('37', 37, 3, 7, 73525) As a matter of fact, neither has any promise of success unless the greater part of the nation supports it.
('37', 37, 4, 8, 73632) 4. It is not accurate to liken a strike to an economic blockade.
('37', 37, 4, 9, 73697) So far as there is danger of hunger, it would be the strikers themselves who would suffer first.
('37', 37, 4, 10, 73794) In actual fact, in the recent General Strike, the T.U.C. (Trade Union Congress) was prepared to co operate in maintaining life and health.
('37', 37, 4, 11, 73933) The Government refused co operation.
('37', 37, 5, 12, 73970) 5. The determining factor as to whether a strike is pacifist or not is the spirit from which it springs.
('37', 37, 5, 13, 74075) A strike against war in which the motive was hatred of members of the Government rather than of war and which represented a spirit which might be transformed into civil war, would not be an act of pacifism, nor would a strike against wage reductions animated by hatred of the employers or of members of the Government, or by anti social feeling.
('37', 37, 5, 14, 74421) But both are acts of pacifism when inspired by the spirit of protest against the evils themselves.
('37', 37, 6, 15, 74520) 6. Whilst it is admitted that a non pacifist spirit occasionally showed itself in the utterances, and still more rarely in the acts of strikers, I have not the least hesitation in saying that the dominant motive in the Great Strike was that of self sacrificing moral protest and not anti social force or personal hatred.
('37', 37, 6, 16, 74841) It was this which gave it spiritual power; in this the secret of the wonderful self discipline of the men was to be found.
('37', 37, 7, 17, 74964) A pacifism which can only see the cruelties of occasional military warfare and is blind to the continuous cruelties of our social system is worthless.
('37', 37, 7, 18, 75115) Unless our pacifism finds expression in the broad human movement which is seeking not merely the end of war, but our equally non pacifist civilization as a whole, it will be of little account in the onward march of mankind.
('37', 37, 7, 19, 75339) The spirit of life will sweep on, quite uninfluenced by it.
('37', 37, 8, 20, 75399) The No More War Movement will fulfil its purpose just in so far as it recognizes this.
('37', 37, 8, 21, 75486) I would only add to these admirable conditions one more test.
('37', 37, 8, 22, 75548) A pacific strike must be limited to those who are labouring under the grievance to be redressed.
('37', 37, 8, 23, 75645) Thus if the match manufacturers, say, of Timbuctoo, who are quite satisfied with their lot, strike out of sym 
('37', 38, 0, 1, 75756) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 39
('37', 38, 1, 2, 75803) pathy for its millhands who are getting starvation wages, the match manufacturers’ strike would be a species of violence.
('37', 38, 1, 3, 75925) They may and should help in a most effective manner by withdrawing their custom from the millowners of Timbuctoo without laying themselves open to the charge of violence.
('37', 38, 1, 4, 76096) But it is possible to conceive occasions when those who are not directly suffering may be under an obligation to cease work.
('37', 38, 1, 5, 76221) Thus if, in the instance imagined, the masters in the match factory combine with the millowners of Timbuctoo, it will clearly be the duty of the workers in the match factory to make common cause with the mill hands.
('37', 38, 1, 6, 76437) But I have suggested the addition purely by way of illustration.
('37', 38, 1, 7, 76502) In the last resort, every case has to be judged on its own merits.
('37', 38, 1, 8, 76569) Violence is a subtle force.
('37', 38, 1, 9, 76597) It is not easy always to detect its presence though you may feel it all the same.
('37', 38, 1, 10, 76679) Young India, 18 11 1926
('37', 38, 2, 11, 76703) 43. NOTES
('37', 38, 3, 12, 76713) RAMACHANDRAN LIFT Numerous letters have been received both by Mr. Ramach andran and me regarding the Ramachandran Animal Power Lift.
('37', 38, 3, 13, 76846) Some ask to be supplied with the lift at once, others ask pertinent questions about it.
('37', 38, 3, 14, 76934) Mr. Ramachandran has left all the letters with me.
('37', 38, 3, 15, 76985) The lift is patented.
('37', 38, 3, 16, 77007) The inventor has no lift ready to supply.
('37', 38, 3, 17, 77049) He has to get it manufactured.
('37', 38, 3, 18, 77080) He has not the means to attend to many orders with despatch.
('37', 38, 3, 19, 77141) I am, therefore, trying to secure facili ties for rapid manufacture.
('37', 38, 3, 20, 77210) The inventor has proceeded to Madras to attend to his affairs and prepare to give his whole time to the supervision of manufacture and putting up the lift.
('37', 38, 3, 21, 77366) I, therefore, urge the correspon dents to be a little patient and await the nece ssary arrangements that must be made before a supply can be commenced.
('37', 38, 3, 22, 77518) An endeavour is being made to nationalize the manufacture and to secure the lowest possible quotations for the lift.
('37', 38, 3, 23, 77635) Correspondents will forgive me for not replying individually to their letters.
('37', 38, 3, 24, 77714) I deal below with some of the points raised by them: 1. If the arrangements that are pending go through, I hope to publish a diagram with the letterpress.
('37', 38, 3, 25, 77869) 2. The parts are not at all complicated; on the contrary, the plan is incredibly simple.
('37', 38, 3, 26, 77958) It is undoubtedly designed to answer village requirements.
('37', 39, 0, 1, 78017) 40 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 39, 1, 2, 78058) 3. Small lengths of rails, pulleys and wire ropes have to be supplied from cities.
('37', 39, 1, 3, 78141) 4. The lift should last several years.
('37', 39, 1, 4, 78180) The bucket and the rope may require more frequent replacement.
('37', 39, 1, 5, 78243) 5. So far as I can see, an ordinary village blacksmith should be able to attend to such repairs as may become necessary.
('37', 39, 1, 6, 78364) 6. The lift must be fixed by a skilled mechanic.
('37', 39, 1, 7, 78413) The weights, the incline, etc., have to be adjusted.
('37', 39, 1, 8, 78466) The rails must be truly laid.
('37', 39, 1, 9, 78496) The pulley must be in its proper position.
('37', 39, 1, 10, 78539) But I understand that a man with ordinary intelligence can be easily and quickly trained to fix the lift with its appurtenances.
('37', 39, 1, 11, 78668) The mechanic will have to be paid his travelling expenses, etc.
('37', 39, 1, 12, 78732) These details are now being attended to.
('37', 39, 1, 13, 78773) 7. The most economical way is to use a heavy male buffalo, the heavier the animal, the larger the quantity of water it will carry without any exertion.
('37', 39, 1, 14, 78925) 8. The empty trolley is carried up by the weight of the bucket.
('37', 39, 1, 15, 78989) 9. The bucket is as a rule 40 lbs.
('37', 39, 1, 16, 79024) in weight, the trolley 100 lbs.
('37', 39, 1, 17, 79056) 10. The lift can be employed for any depth, even 125 ft., i.e., it is capable of being used wherever the ordinary mhote can be.
('37', 39, 2, 18, 79184) KHADI SALES During the period of probation the problem of the sale of khadi is as great as, if not greater than, that of production.
('37', 39, 2, 19, 79317) Hitherto, the sales have not kept pace with production.
('37', 39, 2, 20, 79373) The best managed province for sales is undoubtedly Bengal.
('37', 39, 2, 21, 79432) The tone set by the Khadi Pratishthan, the creation of Dr. Ray and his lieutenant Satis Chandra Das Guptahas been kept up by the organizations that have grown up there.
('37', 39, 2, 22, 79603) Bengal has also striven with considerable success to manu facture according to local needs.
('37', 39, 2, 23, 79695) This is sound economy.
('37', 39, 2, 24, 79718) The method has enabled the workers to come and keep in touch with the buying middle class at the one end and the manufacturing poor class at the other.
('37', 39, 2, 25, 79870) The consequence is a steady improvement in texture, variety and pattern and in prices from the buyer’s point of view.
('37', 39, 2, 26, 79988) The re markable fact about the growing cheapness of khadi is that gener ally the reduction in prices has not meant a corresponding reduction in wages of carders, spinners and weavers, but has been due to better knowledge and greater efficiency.
('37', 39, 2, 27, 80233) The latest instance of organized sales comes from Sylhet.
('37', 39, 2, 28, 80291) Dhirendranath Das Gupta has been managing only a small khadi centre at Kulaura near Sylhet.
('37', 39, 2, 29, 80383) He reports that he sold during the Puja
('37', 40, 0, 1, 80423) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 41
('37', 40, 1, 2, 80470) holidays only over Rs. 2,600 worth of khadi.
('37', 40, 1, 3, 80515) Though there is no doubt that in the other provinces, too, considerable improvement has been made as in Bengal, the sales have not been so methodically organized as there.
('37', 40, 1, 4, 80687) Bihar is trying to come very near Bengal.
('37', 40, 1, 5, 80729) But the workers all over the provinces should devise methods of stimulating sales.
('37', 40, 1, 6, 80812) The experiences of Mr. Bharucha and other veterans should be pooled and schemes with variations suiting the various provinces should be devised and put into operation.
('37', 40, 1, 7, 80980) Hawking and peripatetic exhibitions have come to stay.
('37', 40, 1, 8, 81035) There is danger of all these schemes being top heavy if the minutest details are not worked out.
('37', 40, 1, 9, 81132) There are some stores in the different parts of India which from this standpoint should perhaps be closed.
('37', 40, 1, 10, 81239) A store costing Rs. 500 per year and selling no more is one that is fit to be closed.
('37', 40, 1, 11, 81325) There is gross mismanagement or ignorance about it.

('37', 42, 2, 7, 86377) WIDOWS AND WIDOWERS A correspondent writes:
('37', 42, 3, 8, 86421) I have carefully read the correspondence “A Catechism” and your replies published in the Young India dated 14th October ‘26. While answering the first question of the correspondent on page 357 in para first in the concluding portion, you say, “I should any day subscribe to a reform in the Hindu Law making sinful the remarriage of a widow or a widower who voluntarily married after maturity.”
('37', 42, 4, 9, 86815) In my opinion, a reform of this kind in the Hindu Law will be disastrous and to a large extent affect the moral standard of the society as a whole.
('37', 42, 4, 10, 86963) For instance if a man or a woman married after maturity and unfortunately happens to lose either his wife or her husband after some days of married life, do you mean to say that the man or the woman should not be allowed to remarry even though a great desire of enjoying married life is left unfulfilled, for the only reason that the man or the woman concerned married after maturity?
('37', 42, 4, 11, 87348) If a reform of this kind is made in the Hindu Law, I am afraid the man or the woman will find out some immoral way of gratifying his or her unsatisfied desire and there will be a wholesale moral corruption in the society.
('37', 42, 4, 12, 87570) I therefore think that this question should entirely be left to the discretion of the man or woman concerned.
('37', 42, 4, 13, 87680) My reply to the catechist was a challenge to man who is the law giver.
('37', 42, 4, 14, 87751) He will not allow his liberty to be restricted.
('37', 42, 4, 15, 87799) My reply, therefore, is an attempt to show that what is considered desirable for man should be equally so for women and that, therefore, a widow should have the same discretion as a widower about remarriage.
('37', 42, 4, 16, 88007) Moreover, the Hindu
('37', 43, 0, 1, 88027) 44 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 43, 1, 2, 88068) Law is not inelastic like the laws made under the British Constitution.
('37', 43, 1, 3, 88140) It will be noticed that I have deliberately used the word ‘sinful’ instead of criminal.
('37', 43, 1, 4, 88228) A crime carries with it punishment imposed by a man worked State.
('37', 43, 1, 5, 88294) A sin is punishable only by God or one’s conscience.
('37', 43, 1, 6, 88347) And I do think that, if Hindu society would rise to the level I have aimed at in my answer, it will be a great gain for it and humanity.

('37', 51, 6, 16, 102422) 56. IS THIS HUMANITY?—VII
('37', 51, 7, 17, 102448) [November 21, 1926] Some of my correspondents do not seem to realize the funda mental consideration underlying my suggestion for the destruc tion of dogs under certain circumstances.
('37', 51, 7, 18, 102631) Thus, for instance, I have not made the suggestion in a purely utilitarian spirit.
('37', 51, 7, 19, 102714) The utility to society incidentally accrues from the act, but the principal consi deration is the relief of the long drawn out agony of the creatures whose present condition it is simply impossible for me to tolerate.
('37', 51, 7, 20, 102932) In the articles in this series, there has not been even the remo test suggestion that man has the right of disposal over the lower animals and that he may, therefore, kill them for his own comfort or pleasure.
('37', 51, 7, 21, 103142) One of the writers betrays a strange confusion of thought when he says that the characteristic of an exalted soul is that he remains unaffected by the misery around him.
('37', 51, 7, 22, 103312) He is callous, rather than exalted, who has not learnt to melt at others’ woe, who has not learnt to see himself in others and others in himself.
('37', 51, 7, 23, 103458) Intense longing for the happiness of others was the mother of the discovery of ahimsa.
('37', 51, 7, 24, 103545) And the sage who was the embodiment of compassion found his soul’s delight in re nouncing his own physical comfort and stopped killing for his pleas ure the dumb creation about him.
('37', 51, 8, 25, 103727) 1 The postmark bears the date, “23 11 1926”, Wardha, where the addressee received it.
('37', 52, 0, 1, 103813) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 53
('37', 52, 1, 2, 103860) A correspondent reminds me of the advice given me by Shri Rajchandra when I approached him with a doubt as to what I should do if a serpent threatened to bite me.
('37', 52, 1, 3, 104023) Certainly his advice was that, rather than kill the serpent, I should allow myself to be killed by it.
('37', 52, 1, 4, 104126) But the correspondent forgets that it is not myself that is the subject matter of the present discussion, but the welfare of society in general as also of the suffering animals.
('37', 52, 1, 5, 104304) If I had approached Raychandbhai with the question whether I should or should not kill a serpent writh ing in agony, and whose pain I could not relieve otherwise, or whether I should or should not kill a serpent threatening to bite a child under my protection, if I could not otherwise turn the reptile away, I do not know what what answer he would have given.
('37', 52, 1, 6, 104665) For me the answer is clear as daylight and I have given it.
('37', 52, 1, 7, 104725) A studious correspondent confronts me with some verses from aJain philosopher and asks if I agree with the position taken up in them.
('37', 52, 1, 8, 104859) One of the verses says:
('37', 52, 2, 9, 104883) One should not kill even beasts of prey in the belief that by killing one such, one saves the lives of many.
('37', 52, 2, 10, 104992) Another says:
('37', 52, 3, 11, 105006) Nor should one kill them out of a compassionate feeling that if they were suffered to live longer they might sink deeper into sin.
('37', 52, 3, 12, 105137) The third verse says:
('37', 52, 4, 13, 105159) Nor should one kill distressed creatures presuming that one would thereby shorten the length of their agony.
('37', 52, 4, 14, 105268) To me the meaning of the verses is clear.
('37', 52, 4, 15, 105310) And it is this that a particular theory should not be the spring of action in any case.
('37', 52, 4, 16, 105398) You may commit himsa, not in order that you thereby realize in practice a pet theory of yours, but because you are driven to it as an imperative duty.
('37', 52, 4, 17, 105549) Work which spontaneously comes to one’s lot, or action without attachment, in the words of the Gita, is the duty of a seeker after moksha.
('37', 52, 4, 18, 105688) Confine your energy to work that comes your way, I con ceive the Jain philosopher to say, never seek fresh fields of acti vity.
('37', 52, 4, 19, 105816) The verses, to me, define the mental attitude of detachment that should govern one’s action in cases where himsa seems to be imperative and unavoidable.
('37', 52, 4, 20, 105969) But I have arrived at my present views independently of any authority, though originally they may have been drawn from various sources, and I submit that they are in perfect consonance with ahimsa,
('37', 53, 0, 1, 106167) 54 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 53, 1, 2, 106208) even though they may be proved to be contrary to the teaching of the philosopher.

('37', 53, 2, 4, 106314) 57. KHADI FROM YAJNA YARN
('37', 53, 3, 5, 106340) A member of the All India Spinners’ Association writes as follows:
('37', 53, 4, 6, 106407) Khadi is woven from the yarn received from the members and then it is sold.
('37', 53, 4, 7, 106483) How are the proceeds utilized?
('37', 53, 4, 8, 106514) Would it be wrong if this khadi was supplied to the poor at a cheaper rate, charging only the weaving expenses, etc.?
('37', 53, 4, 9, 106632) What advantage do you find in the present system?
('37', 53, 4, 10, 106682) I wish you to clarify this matter through Navajivan.
('37', 53, 4, 11, 106735) I think that this question has already been answered once.
('37', 53, 4, 12, 106794) The yajna yarn is received in a very limited quantityand though its quality is improving day by day and so irregularly that it can just cover the expenses of collecting and storing.
('37', 53, 4, 13, 106977) Hence the khadi made from this yarn is sold at ordinary rates.
('37', 53, 4, 14, 107040) Sufficient khadi to meet the demands of poor people is produced neither from yajna yarn nor from any other yarn.
('37', 53, 4, 15, 107153) But the yajna yarn amply feeds the poor.
('37', 53, 4, 16, 107194) The khadi that is produced out of the yarn spun by the poor costs more per yard than mill made cloth.
('37', 53, 4, 17, 107296) Yet the middle and the rich classes are trying to ensure the success of the art of spinning by purchasing it.
('37', 53, 4, 18, 107406) When this yajna which is now being performed on a small scale becomes widespread, khadi will be given almost free to the poor, while the rich and the middle classes will wear khadi available at low price.
('37', 53, 4, 19, 107611) At present the yarn received by the Spinners’ Association satisfies the sentiment which when developed will fulfil the material need.
('37', 53, 4, 20, 107745) If the Spinners’ Association has no members and if [for membership] there is no condition of good spinning, then there would be no one carrying on khadi work as at present.
('37', 53, 4, 21, 107918) Thus even though the poor are not enabled to wear khadi made of yarn received by the Spinners’ Association, yet they derive all the benefits of its activities.
('37', 53, 4, 22, 108078) The very existence of the Spinners’ Association is for the benefit of the poor.

('37', 63, 1, 4, 124731) A TISSUE OF MISREPRESENTATIONS A friend sent me some time ago an article written about me in The Nineteenth Century and After.
('37', 63, 1, 5, 124858) I glanced through it, but it contained so many misrepresentations that I did not think it worth while reading it through, nor did I feel inclined to contradict the many falsehoods contained in it.
('37', 63, 1, 6, 125055) Those who would credit them were not likely to be affected by any contradiction from me.
('37', 63, 1, 7, 125144) But now a law student who, from the tone of his letter, has felt deeply hurt by the article, which he does not believe, wants me to deal with two specific statements.
('37', 63, 1, 8, 125311) They are:
('37', 63, 2, 9, 125321) In one of the schools which owed allegiance to Gandhi, a high caste parent refused co education of his son with the out caste, and a high caste teacher refused to teach a low caste boy.
('37', 63, 2, 10, 125507) The question was referred to Gandhi who upheld the high caste men.
('37', 63, 2, 11, 125574) That he said he would have helped the untouchables if he could does not excuse him.
('37', 63, 3, 12, 125658) The papers of the time published statements to the effect that Gandhi was busy over his work of collection in Bombay and could not come just then, etc.
('37', 63, 3, 13, 125810) They are both false.
('37', 63, 3, 14, 125831) Those who know my work about untouch ables know that I have resisted, at the risk of losing friendships and donations to public causes, any attempt to discriminate against untou chables in national institutions.
('37', 63, 3, 15, 126043) There is half truth in the statement about Chandpur.
('37', 63, 3, 16, 126096) I did not go there when the trouble broke out.
('37', 63, 3, 17, 126143) But the reason given by the writer is utterly devoid of truth.
('37', 63, 3, 18, 126206) I am not omnipotent.
('37', 63, 3, 19, 126227) I have only a limited sphere of work.
('37', 63, 3, 20, 126265) I apply myself to the task that comes to me.
('37', 63, 3, 21, 126310) I go only where I am wanted and where I regard myself competent to render some service.
('37', 63, 3, 22, 126398) Thus I do not now run to places where Hindus and Mussalmans fight, not because I do not want to go or am preoccupied, but because I feel powerless.
('37', 63, 3, 23, 126546) Nor do I rush wherever labour troubles occur, even though I may be invited.
('37', 63, 3, 24, 126622) The work I was then doing had nothing to do with my not going to Chandpur.
('37', 63, 3, 25, 126697) If I had felt the call I would have gone at all cost.
('37', 63, 3, 26, 126751) The law student and others who are interested in me will do well not to be disturbed over misrepresentations regarding me.
('37', 63, 3, 27, 126874) They are
('37', 64, 0, 1, 126883) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 65
('37', 64, 1, 2, 126930) the lot of public workers.
('37', 64, 1, 3, 126957) My reputation will not suffer by misrepre sentations.
('37', 64, 1, 4, 127011) It certainly will when I am guilty of misconduct.
('37', 64, 1, 5, 127061) No whitewashing will then save it.
('37', 64, 1, 6, 127096) But today my withers are unwrung even though a German friend tells me that a German paper accuses me of having promoted a film company.
('37', 64, 1, 7, 127232) The innocent writer does not know that I have never once been to a cinema and refuse to be enthused about it and waste God given time in spite of pressure sometimes used by kind friends.
('37', 64, 1, 8, 127419) They tell me it has an educational value.

('37', 64, 1, 11, 127553) Education, therefore, I seek elsewhere.

('37', 65, 4, 8, 129976) C. F. Andrews has sent me the following characteristic cable gram:
('37', 65, 5, 9, 130043) Executive decided observe December nineteenth day prayer forth coming Conference.
('37', 65, 5, 10, 130125) Churches co operating.

('37', 65, 5, 13, 130248) He is an intensely godly man and, therefore, a man of prayer.
('37', 65, 5, 14, 130310) His politics are guided, coloured and ennobled by his prayers.
('37', 65, 5, 15, 130373) Prayer with him is no empty formula.
('37', 65, 5, 16, 130410) It is with him intense and incessant communion with God and waiting upon Him for guidance is his daily work great and small.
('37', 65, 5, 17, 130535) No work that is done in His name and dedicated to Him is small.
('37', 65, 5, 18, 130599) All work when so done assumes equal merit.
('37', 65, 5, 19, 130642) A scavenger who works in His service shares equal distinction with a king who uses his gifts in His name and as a mere trustee.
('37', 65, 5, 20, 130770) Unlike as among us very imperfect beings, in His Durbar the motive rather than the act itself decides its quality.
('37', 65, 5, 21, 130885) We infer the intention from the act.
('37', 65, 5, 22, 130922) He, knowing the intention as much as the act, judges the act according to the intention.
('37', 65, 5, 23, 131011) And Andrews, because his intentions are the purest possible, believes that God will ensure his success.
('37', 65, 5, 24, 131115) He has every reason for his belief.

('37', 67, 0, 1, 134162) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 67, 1, 2, 134203) 70. CURIOUS IDEAS 1
('37', 67, 2, 3, 134223) This is a joint production from the teachers of a Board High School.
('37', 67, 2, 4, 134292) It is therefore a somewhat representative and responsible document.
('37', 67, 2, 5, 134360) But for this character the letter bears, I should not have published it.
('37', 67, 2, 6, 134433) The campaign against untouchability and other social and religious reforms is bringing to light grotesque and subtle ideas held even by men of learning.
('37', 67, 2, 7, 134586) The defence offered by the teachers of gross superstitions shows how argument follows conviction, and, there fore, shows what a small place argument holds in any great move ment.
('37', 67, 2, 8, 134765) It is the example of the reformer that matters.
('37', 67, 2, 9, 134813) And when that example assumes power by being proof against misrepresentation, calumny, and persecution even to the point of death, the reform spreads.
('37', 67, 2, 10, 134964) So will it be with untouchability and the like.
('37', 67, 2, 11, 135012) But let us evaluate these teachers’ arguments for a while.
('37', 67, 2, 12, 135071) In the first instance, they have chosen a bad analogy.
('37', 67, 2, 13, 135126) I do not know that people are afraid to approach me or to touch me.
('37', 67, 2, 14, 135194) On the contrary, whenever I travel, I am embarrassed by the over attention of crowds wanting to touch me.
('37', 67, 2, 15, 135300) They will not leave me alone even while I am taking my bath.
('37', 67, 2, 16, 135361) Secondly, if our untouchable countrymen are afraid to touch the higher caste men, surely it is not because of the latter’s greater purity, but because they have been taught not to touch them and because of the knowledge that any attempt to touch would be followed by abuse or worse.
('37', 67, 2, 17, 135644) Thirdly, the inferiority, in point of character, of the untoucha bles is an unwarranted assumption.
('37', 67, 2, 18, 135744) Class considered, probably they are in no way inferior to the others for truthfulness, purity and other public and private virtues, which under favourable circumstances they have been capable of exhibiting as fully as any.
('37', 67, 2, 19, 135967) It is a misuse of the doctrine of previous birth to argue that these people will require generations before they can come up to the level of the so called high castes.
('37', 67, 2, 20, 136135) The Gita teaches us that it is as open to an untouchable as to a learned pundit to attain salvation in the existing birth.
('37', 67, 2, 21, 136258) If the high castes are really higher, they should have no fear of association with the untouchables.
('37', 67, 2, 22, 136359) For the latter can only gain by such
('37', 67, 3, 23, 136396) 1 These ideas were embodied in a joint statement, not reproduced here, in which the authors had questioned the wisdom of Gandhiji’s anti untouchability campaign, pleaded for sattvic food, suggested that Gandhiji should take to the yoga of the rishis, and persuade some of his followers to live and work in villages.
('37', 68, 0, 1, 136712) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 69
('37', 68, 1, 2, 136759) superior contact without the former becoming in any way degraded especially when they mix among the untouchables for the sake of service and not for the sake of mere sociableness in which there is mutual give and take of vice and virtue.
('37', 68, 1, 3, 136997) I do not become contam inated by entering a public house if I enter it as a reformer with the intention of weaning the drunkard from his habit as I would be contaminated if I entered a public house with a friend to keep him company and without any preconceived determination of resisting the temptation that the public house or the friend may place in my way.
('37', 68, 1, 4, 137357) Equally strange is the argument of the teachers regarding the influence of food on character.
('37', 68, 1, 5, 137451) I am a keen food reformer, many friends consider me to be fanatical in my zeal for food reform and for reducing one’s food to the simplest terms possible.
('37', 68, 1, 6, 137606) But I know that the teachers are attaching importance to food out of all proportion and the influence it exerts upon character.
('37', 68, 1, 7, 137734) If public work were to be suspended till public workers were found who would avoid all condi ments and subscribe to a rigid food formula, there would be no public work done.
('37', 68, 1, 8, 137908) One can only press the advantages of a simple, frugal and non stimulating diet upon workers.
('37', 68, 1, 9, 138001) But one dare not stop all public activity till that reform has been achieved.

('37', 74, 2, 7, 147914) God having created him so weak, how can he describe an actual event perfectly?
('37', 74, 2, 8, 147993) In this battle, moreover, the warriors were, on the one side, the sons 4 of Dharma, Vayu, Indra and Ashvinikumars and, on the other, a hundred brothers 5 all born at the same instant.
