('37', 355, 5, 22, 787707) 84. IS THIS HUMANITY?—VIII
('37', 355, 6, 23, 787734) [November 28, 1926] Letters on this subject are still pouring in, but I fail to discover in them any new question or any fresh argument advanced.
('37', 355, 6, 24, 787880) I would therefore ask those who have been thinking on this subject to read this series of articles over and over again.
('37', 355, 6, 25, 788000) I do so without the slightest hesitation, inasmuch as they are the result not of ideas hastily formed, but of experience of many years.
('37', 355, 6, 26, 788136) I have presented no new principles, but have tried to restate old principles.
('37', 355, 6, 27, 788214) I cannot say how far the presentation is correct, but as it represents my honest conviction, and
('37', 356, 0, 1, 788311) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 357
('37', 356, 1, 2, 788359) as many friends expect me to solve intricate problems in ahimsa, I can only ask them to turn to the series I have been writing.
('37', 356, 1, 3, 788487) Some of my correspondents wrench my own sentences from their contexts and quote them against me, some quote part of them and omit the most essential remainder.
('37', 356, 1, 4, 788647) Thus I have never advocated the extirpation of dogs as a class.
('37', 356, 1, 5, 788711) On the contrary my suggestions have been made for their betterment.
('37', 356, 1, 6, 788779) I have repeatedly said that I have suggested the destruction of certain dogs under certain circumstances.
('37', 356, 1, 7, 788885) Even this may be open to question.
('37', 356, 1, 8, 788920) If it is, the objector should address himself only to that and nothing more.
('37', 356, 1, 9, 788997) I continue to be the same votary of ahimsa that I was before.
('37', 356, 1, 10, 789059) I still continue to hold life not only in man and animal, but in plant and flower, as sacred, and yet make use of vegetables and flowers and fruit.
('37', 356, 1, 11, 789207) Only the spirit behind the use is: ‘He that soweth to his flesh shall of the flesh reap corruption; but he that soweth to the spirit shall of the spirit reap life everlasting.’ Destruction of dogs, even as that of plant or vegetable, is advised only when it is a matter of imperative duty, and only when it is meant not to sow to the flesh, but to the spirit.
('37', 356, 1, 12, 789567) What torments me is the impotence of the votary of ahimsa.
('37', 356, 1, 13, 789626) Ahimsa is not impotence.
('37', 356, 1, 14, 789651) Ahimsa is nor powerlessness.
('37', 356, 1, 15, 789680) Ahimsa is unconquerable power.
('37', 356, 1, 16, 789711) We shrink from it as we are dazed by its over powering lustre.
('37', 356, 1, 17, 789774) Only very few of us can catch a glimpse of it.
('37', 356, 1, 18, 789821) Ahimsa is the distinguishing characteristic of an untrammelled spirit.
('37', 356, 1, 19, 789892) It is at the root of a number of other qualities—discrimination, detachment, penance, equability and knowledge.
('37', 356, 1, 20, 790004) It is the way of the brave, not of shrinkers.
('37', 356, 1, 21, 790050) He who would understand ahimsa must understand the meaning of the inevitable himsa one sees about oneself.
('37', 356, 1, 22, 790157) This state ment, I know, is liable to abuse.
('37', 356, 1, 23, 790202) But what is there free from this danger?
('37', 356, 1, 24, 790243) Is not even God’s name turned to the worst account?
('37', 356, 1, 25, 790295) Have not rivers of blood been made to flow in His name?
('37', 356, 1, 26, 790351) Have we not worshipped the Devil in His name?
('37', 356, 1, 27, 790397) But that does not diminish His glory.
('37', 356, 1, 28, 790435) That does not mean that we shall take His name in a secret corner.
('37', 356, 1, 29, 790502) All action is tainted inasmuch as it presupposes himsa.

('37', 356, 1, 31, 790634) This body is the receptacle of sin, and yet we seek to achieve salvation by making of that abode of sin God’s own sanctuary.

('37', 357, 1, 3, 791080) I propose to conclude this series with a brief reference by way of illustration to the way in which we are trying to solve the dog problem in the Ashram.

('37', 357, 1, 11, 791646) Every inmate does not yet realize the necessity of it, and those who do are not sufficiently alive to the observance of the rule.

('37', 361, 4, 8, 800126) CURRENCY
('37', 361, 5, 9, 800135) For the past many years, I have resisted the pressure of friends to study the currency question, not because it is not one of the most important questions engaging public attention but because I have more than enough to do and because I know nothing about the science and I never speak or write on subjects of which I have not acquired a knowledge to my own satisfaction.
('37', 361, 5, 10, 800507) I am now no longer able to resist the pressure.
('37', 361, 5, 11, 800555) The friends urge that I must assist in popularizing its study, and use such influence as I possess among the masses for their education in this vital matter.
('37', 361, 5, 12, 800713) I do not share their enthusiasm.
('37', 361, 5, 13, 800746) I am not sure that the masses can be made to understand the very intricate riddles of currency.
('37', 361, 5, 14, 800842) But I dare not brush aside the weighty statement they make that the present currency policy of the Government if carried out means a strain upon the resources of the dumb millions of India which they are ill able to sustain.
('37', 361, 5, 15, 801067) I have therefore promised to study the question, open the columns of Young India for its discussion and if possible to express my own opinion about it.
('37', 361, 5, 16, 801219) In redemption of that promise I am in a position to publish elsewhere what I hope is the first instalment of a series of articles on

('37', 365, 4, 9, 807366) 95. CULTURE
('37', 365, 5, 10, 807378) Elsewhere I reproduce almost word for word the talk Mahadev Desai gave on the takli during the Youth Week 2, for it embodies his inmost thoughts and the attendant circumstances are worthy of note.
('37', 365, 5, 11, 807575) That speech was not delivered for its own sake.
('37', 365, 5, 12, 807623) But some young men got bored listening to it and they started a disturbance.
('37', 365, 5, 13, 807700) I have often written to say that the practice of causing disturbances does not become India’s culture.
('37', 365, 5, 14, 807803) In this country, at any rate, those who do not like someone’s speech may not pay attention to it, and if they find it repugnant they may walk out.
('37', 365, 5, 15, 807950) But they should not employ force to stop a speaker from speaking.
('37', 365, 5, 16, 808016) To shout down someone is nothing but use of force.
('37', 365, 5, 17, 808067) If intolerance grown among us, it will hamper our progress.
('37', 365, 5, 18, 808127) We have no reason to believe that what we do not like must assuredly be bad.
('37', 365, 5, 19, 808204) Certainly there are many things in the world which taste bitter in the beginning but turn out to be sweet in the end.
('37', 365, 5, 20, 808322) A nation whose youths discard restraint, courtesy, humility and tolerance courts destruction.
('37', 365, 5, 21, 808416) The reins of national life are in the hands of youth alone.
('37', 365, 5, 22, 808476) Their responsibility is greater than that of old people because the latter have given whatever they could or as much as they wished to give [to the nation].
('37', 365, 5, 23, 808633) Youths are today shaping the new order and making fresh contributions.
('37', 365, 5, 24, 808704) Those who had made noise forgot this responsibility of theirs.
('37', 365, 5, 25, 808767) Mahadev Desai’s speech was being communicated by his hands.
('37', 365, 5, 26, 808827) Hence it was such as could be followed through the eyes.
('37', 365, 5, 27, 808884) The youths were unable to stop the speech that was being conveyed by the hands.
('37', 365, 6, 28, 808964) 1 For the annual session of the Congress 2 Celebrated at Ahmedabad in November, 1926
('37', 366, 0, 1, 809049) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 367
('37', 366, 1, 2, 809097) When they realized this inability of theirs, they stopped their shouting.
('37', 366, 1, 3, 809171) But they certainly earned discredit by shouting.
('37', 366, 1, 4, 809220) The next day the papers reported that the youths prevented Mahadev Desai from giving his speech on the takli.
('37', 366, 1, 5, 809330) This brought discredit not to Mahadev Desai but to those who had shouted.
('37', 366, 1, 6, 809404) But their discredit is tantamount to our country’s.
('37', 366, 1, 7, 809456) A country’s credit is not distinct from that of its citizens.
('37', 366, 1, 8, 809518) Showing repugnance against the takli is like marching an army against an ant.
('37', 366, 1, 9, 809596) It has been shown in Navajivan by extracts quoted from old books that the takli is one of man’s oldest tools.
('37', 366, 1, 10, 809706) The takli is poor people’s machine, it is their asylum.
('37', 366, 1, 11, 809762) Just as the plough is the means of producing food, so is the takli the means of producing cloth.
('37', 366, 1, 12, 809859) Huge mills may arise out of the takli.
('37', 366, 1, 13, 809898) A spinning mill means a mill containing taklis.
('37', 366, 1, 14, 809946) Just as a man who, plugging the pipe connections to the different houses, trains them towards his own house and thereby makes others dependent on him for water supply, a spinning mill too makes independent spinners dependent by getting within itself all the various taklis.
('37', 366, 1, 15, 810220) Thus, a takli is a symbol of freedom, a mill that of dependence.
('37', 366, 1, 16, 810285) How then can one dislike such a thing as a means of support?
('37', 366, 1, 17, 810346) It is our duty to realize the power of that tiny thing.
('37', 366, 1, 18, 810402) He who makes us realize its power deserves our gratitude, deserves a good turn from us.
('37', 366, 2, 19, 810490) Just as we should starve if we renounced the plough, we have become naked by giving up the takli.
('37', 366, 2, 20, 810588) Because a few get clothes, we should not think that crores of people also get them.
('37', 366, 2, 21, 810672) Records prove that lakhs of our brothers and sisters go about naked and suffer from hunger.
('37', 366, 2, 22, 810764) The takli has a twofold power—to cover the body and to feed it—because spinning provides us with cloth and the money saved thereby goes to augment our power of purchasing food.
('37', 366, 2, 23, 810941) Hence I have given to the takli or the spinning wheel the name of Annapurna 1. The takli dispels our lethargy, covers our body and supports it.
('37', 366, 2, 24, 811085) How can such an implement be disliked?
('37', 366, 2, 25, 811124) Moreover, a takli brings us into contact with our poor brethren and enables us to share their hardships.
('37', 366, 2, 26, 811229) The sages have given us through a story poem an idea of the power of a tiny blade of grass.
('37', 366, 2, 27, 811321) The wind could not blow it away.
('37', 366, 2, 28, 811354) The fire could not burn it up.
('37', 366, 2, 29, 811385) Someone may well ignore a blade of grass
('37', 366, 3, 30, 811426) 1 Goddess of plenty
('37', 367, 0, 1, 811446) 368 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 367, 1, 2, 811488) considering it worthy of contempt, but if countless numbers of them were not there we would get neither food nor water.
('37', 367, 1, 3, 811608) The power that lies hidden in a tiny blade of grass also lies hidden in the takli.
('37', 367, 1, 4, 811691) I request those who have scoffed at the takli to read the dialogue between Yaksha and the gods.

('37', 376, 3, 6, 825858) It is to one’s advantage to let the mind become a little insensitive.
('37', 376, 3, 7, 825928) Thinking overmuch is not a good sign.
('37', 376, 3, 8, 825966) Just as it is a sign of disease if the heart beat is too slow or too fast, so is it with the mind.
('37', 376, 3, 9, 826065) To be equiminded, one has to avoid being both.
('37', 376, 3, 10, 826112) It is a rather unusual state of mind.
('37', 376, 3, 11, 826150) Lacking a word to describe it, we speak of it as something which means that one is neither too sensitive nor too insensitive, but that is not so.
('37', 376, 3, 12, 826296) It is something quite different from this since equi minded means suspension of both states of sensitivity and insen sitivity.
('37', 376, 3, 13, 826423) You should try to cultivate such a state of mind.
('37', 376, 3, 14, 826473) However, it may be said that it cannot even be cultivated.
('37', 376, 3, 15, 826532) What you need to do, therefore, is to overcome your sensitiveness.

('37', 377, 1, 2, 827282) 112. PRICE OF FREEDOM
('37', 377, 2, 3, 827304) Mr. Gregg sends me 1 the following extracts from a written address by Thomas Paine to the soldiers of General George Washin gton’s American army in the Revolutionary War, December 1776, fighting against the British for the freedom of the thirteen American Colonies:
('37', 377, 3, 4, 827570) These are the times that try men’s souls.
('37', 377, 3, 5, 827612) The summer soldier and the sunshine patriot will, in this crisis, shrink from the service of his country; but he that stands it now deserves the love and thanks of man and woman.
('37', 377, 3, 6, 827791) Tyranny, like hell, is not easily conquered; yet we have this consolation with us, that the harder the conflict, the more glorious the triumph.
('37', 377, 3, 7, 827935) What we obtain too cheap we esteem too lightly; ’tis dearness only that gives everything its value.
('37', 377, 3, 8, 828035) Heaven knows how to put a proper price upon its goods; and it would be strange indeed, if so celestial an article as Freedom should not be highly rated.
('37', 377, 4, 9, 828188) I once felt all that kind of anger, which a man ought to feel against the mean principles that are held by the Tories: a noted one, who kept a tavern at Amboy, was standing at his door, with as pretty a child in his hand, about eight or nine years old, as I ever saw, and after speaking his mind as freely as he thought was prudent, finished with this unfatherly expression, “Well, give me peace in my day.’ Not a man lives on the continent but fully believes that a separation must some time or other finally take place, and a generous parent should have said, ‘If there must be trouble, let it be in my day that my child may have peace,’ and this single reflection, well applied, is sufficient to awaken every man to duty.
('37', 377, 4, 10, 828913) Not a place upon earth might be so happy as America.
('37', 377, 4, 11, 828966) Her situation is remote from all the wrangling world, and she has nothing to do but to trade with them .
('37', 377, 5, 12, 829071) I call not upon a few, but upon all, not on this state or that state, but on every state; up and help us; lay your shoulders to the wheel; better have too much force than too little, when so great an object is at stake.
('37', 377, 5, 13, 829291) Let it be told to the future world, that in the depth of winter, when nothing but hope and virtue could survive, the city and the country, alarmed at one common danger, came forth to meet and to repulse it.
('37', 377, 5, 14, 829498) Say not that thousands are gone, turn out your tens of thousands; throw not the burden of the day upon Providence, but ‘show your faith by your works’ that God may bless you.
('37', 377, 5, 15, 829673) It matters not where you live, or what rank of life you hold, the evil or the blessing will reach you all.
('37', 377, 5, 16, 829780) The far and the near, the home countries and back, the rich and the poor, will
('37', 377, 6, 17, 829859) 1 Vide “Letter to Richard B. Gregg”, 27 11 1926.
('37', 378, 0, 1, 829908) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 379
('37', 378, 1, 2, 829956) suffer or rejoice alike.
('37', 378, 1, 3, 829981) The heart that feels not now is dead; the blood of his children will curse his cowardice, who shrinks back at a time when a little might have saved the whole, and made them happy.
('37', 378, 1, 4, 830161) I love the man that can smile in trouble, that can gather strength from distress, and grow brave by reflection.
('37', 378, 1, 5, 830273) ’Tis the business of little minds to shrink; but he whose heart is firm, and whose conscience approves his conduct, will pursue his principles unto death .
('37', 378, 2, 6, 830429) There are cases which cannot be overdone by language, and this is one.
('37', 378, 2, 7, 830500) There are persons too who see not the full extent of the evil which threatens them; they solace themselves with hopes that the enemy, if he succeed, will be merciful.
('37', 378, 2, 8, 830667) It is the madness of folly to expect mercy from those who have refused to do justice; and even mercy, where conquest is the object, is only a trick of war; the cunning of the fox is as murderous as the violence of the wolf, and we ought to guard equally against both.
('37', 378, 2, 9, 830935) It is remarkable how similar are the qualities required of soldiers of peace and soldiers of war.
('37', 378, 2, 10, 831033) Thomas Paine’s speech could be addressed almost word for word and with complete appropriateness to the Congress volunteers of 1921 who enrolled under the Ahmedabad Congress pledge of complete non violence in thought word and deed.
('37', 378, 2, 11, 831264) Whether you secure freedom by the use of physical force or spiritual force, i.e., through self suffering, the price to be paid must be heavy, if it is to be a valuable article.
('37', 378, 2, 12, 831441) Bravery and perseverance in the face of odds are as necessary, if not more, to the man of the spirit as to the man of the sword.
('37', 378, 2, 13, 831570) Whether we will win swaraj by violent means or non violent, we shall have to discard ease and comfort, not to speak of luxuries.
('37', 378, 2, 14, 831699) Pratap reduced himself to penury for the sake of what he believed to be freedom.
('37', 378, 2, 15, 831780) Prahlad delivered his body for free destruc tion for what he believed to be his freedom.
('37', 378, 2, 16, 831869) But there are among us not a few who would gain swaraj for a song.
('37', 378, 2, 17, 831936) Thomas Paine tells us that such a thing is not possible.
('37', 378, 3, 18, 831993) Young India, 9 12 1926
('37', 379, 0, 1, 832016) 380 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 379, 1, 2, 832058) 113. THE GREATEST GOOD OF ALL
('37', 379, 2, 3, 832088) A constant reader of Young India sends the following: 1
('37', 379, 3, 4, 832144) I reproduce this letter for it helps me to elucidate my own posi tion.
('37', 379, 3, 5, 832215) If such a very careful reader of Young India, as I know this correspondent is, misunderstands my position as is evident from his letter, how many more occasional readers must have done likewise?
('37', 379, 3, 6, 832410) Several readers did draw my attention to the danger of a misunder standing arising owing to the traditional hardness of our hearts which makes us prone to seize every opportunity of doing violence.
('37', 379, 3, 7, 832608) One can only be—one ought to be—most careful in the h n andling of delicate problems; but no fear of misuse of statements can be permitted to stop a free and honest discussion of fundamental truths.
('37', 379, 3, 8, 832807) For me, I shall learn to be and do right only by prayerful discussion, elucidation and interchange of views.
('37', 379, 3, 9, 832916) This letter I have quoted is an instance in point.
('37', 379, 3, 10, 832967) The discussion has brought to light an honest misunderstanding of difference between the correspondent and myself in the interpretation of the same principle.
('37', 379, 3, 11, 833126) Whilst I am of opinion that Dr. Blazer was well acquitted, accor ding to the test laid down by me, he was wrong in taking the life of his daughter.
('37', 379, 3, 12, 833274) It betrayed want of faith in the humanity of those around him.
('37', 379, 3, 13, 833337) There was no warrant for him to suppose that the daughter would not have been cared for by others.
('37', 379, 3, 14, 833436) The position in the case of dogs under the circumstances assumed by me is materially different from the position in which Dr. Blazer found himself.
('37', 379, 3, 15, 833584) Nor am I able to subscribe to the view that an idiot has no soul.
('37', 379, 3, 16, 833650) I believe that even the lower creation have souls.
('37', 379, 3, 17, 833701) Weightier still is the difficulty which another earnest reader puts and which may be thus summarized: I appreciate the position you have taken up.
('37', 379, 3, 18, 833848) It is the only true position.
('37', 379, 3, 19, 833878) But does not your argument after all resolve itself into the utilitarian doctrine of the greater good of the greater number?
('37', 379, 3, 20, 834003) And if that is your position, wherein does the doctrine of non violence differ from the utilitarian which
('37', 379, 4, 21, 834109) 1 Not reproduced here.
('37', 379, 4, 22, 834132) The correspondent enclosed a newspaper cutting which carried a report of how a Dr. Blazer had chloroformed his imbecile daughter because he felt there would be no one to look after her once he was dead.
('37', 379, 4, 23, 834335) It also carried the report of a French actress who shot her lover at his own request as he was suffering from an incurable disease.
('37', 379, 4, 24, 834467) The jury in both cases acquitted the accused.
('37', 380, 0, 1, 834513) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 381
('37', 380, 1, 2, 834561) makes no pretence to non violence and which will not hesitate to destroy life if the destruction would lead to the greater good of the greater number?
('37', 380, 1, 3, 834712) In the first place even though the outward act may be the same, its implications will vary according to the motive prompting it.
('37', 380, 1, 4, 834841) Thus as non violence in the West stops at man and, even then, only where possible, there is no compunction felt either over subjecting animals to vivisection for the supposed greater good of mankind or over heaping up most destructive armaments also in the name of the same doctrine of utility.
('37', 380, 1, 5, 835136) A votary of non violence, on the other hand, might have done one act of destruction in common with the utilitarian, but he would prefer to die rather than make himself party to vivisection or to an endless multiplication of armaments.
('37', 380, 1, 6, 835371) The fact is that a votary of ahimsa cannot subscribe to the utilitarian formula.
('37', 380, 1, 7, 835452) He will strive for the greatest good of all and die in the attempt to realize the ideal.
('37', 380, 1, 8, 835541) He will therefore be willing to die so that the others may live.
('37', 380, 1, 9, 835606) He will serve himself with the rest, by himself dying.
('37', 380, 1, 10, 835661) The greatest good of all inevitably includes the good of the greater number, and therefore he and the utilitarian will converge at many points in their career but there does come a time when they must part company, and even work in opposite directions.
('37', 380, 1, 11, 835914) The utilitarian to be logical will never sacrifice himself.
('37', 380, 1, 12, 835974) The absolutist will even sacrifice himself.
('37', 380, 1, 13, 836018) The absolutist, when he kills a dog, does so either out of weakness or in rare cases for the sake of the dog himself.
('37', 380, 1, 14, 836136) That it is a dangerous thing to decide what is or is not good for the dog, and that he may therefore make grievous mistakes is irrelevant to the fact of the motive prompting the act.
('37', 380, 1, 15, 836319) The absolutist’s sphere of destruction will be always the narrowest possible.
('37', 380, 1, 16, 836397) The utilitarian’s has no limit.
('37', 380, 1, 17, 836429) Judged by the standard of non violence the late War was wholly wrong.
('37', 380, 1, 18, 836499) Judged by the utilitarian standard each party has justified it according to its idea of utility.
('37', 380, 1, 19, 836596) Even the Jallianwala Bagh massacre was justified by its perpetrators on the grounds of utility.
('37', 380, 1, 20, 836692) And precisely on the same ground the anarchist justifies his assassinations.
('37', 380, 1, 21, 836769) But none of these acts can possibly be justified on the greatest good of all principle.
('37', 380, 1, 22, 836857) Young India, 9 12 1926
('37', 381, 0, 1, 836880) 382 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 381, 1, 2, 836922) 114. NOTES
('37', 381, 2, 3, 836933) INCONGRUITY With my resumed travelling, if it has to be continued, begins my sorrow—crowds coming to have darshan with unmistakable affection in their bright eyes and smiling faces, but doing nothing of what I have ceaselessly poured into their ears.
('37', 381, 2, 4, 837184) On the 4th instant, girls and boys presented to me in the early morning hours at Jalgaon their neatly made strands of hand spun yarn but with a few honourable exceptions, they themselves were dressed in millmade cloth.
('37', 381, 2, 5, 837403) I wonder if the girls and the boys knew why they were spinning at all.
('37', 381, 2, 6, 837474) The girls had been spinning only for four months and they belonged to the municipal school.
('37', 381, 2, 7, 837566) GOOD WORK The report before me of their spinning tells me that the work of introducing spinning in certain schools of the municipality was entrusted to East Khandesh District Khadi Board.
('37', 381, 2, 8, 837754) How businesslike it would be if this example was followed by the other municipalities and orgnization of hand spinning was entrusted to Khadi Boards who are naturally expected to have experts for the work?
('37', 381, 2, 9, 837960) In this school they have both the takli and the charkha.
('37', 381, 2, 10, 838017) The maximum spun by a single girl on the wheel was 7,188 yards of yarn.
('37', 381, 2, 11, 838089) The highest count was 22. The maximum per hour spun on the takli was 120 yards; on the charkha, 375 yards.
('37', 381, 2, 12, 838196) The report says:
('37', 381, 3, 13, 838213) Takli spinning has so much fascinated the girls of standard IV that 15 of them learnt to spin on charkha and have spun during their spare time.
('37', 381, 3, 14, 838357) Their example has induced some girls of standard III also to learn on charkha.
('37', 381, 3, 15, 838436) The contagion is spreading and the number of such voluntary girl spinners is steadily increasing.
('37', 381, 3, 16, 838534) The spinning has become a pastime with some as they come to spin even on holidays.
('37', 381, 3, 17, 838617) 12 prepare their own slivers while 2 have commenced even to learn carding.
('37', 381, 3, 18, 838692) It is to be hoped that before long every girl will card her own cotton and prepare her own slivers and that the teachers will induce the girls to take to wearing khaddar.
('37', 381, 3, 19, 838863) The best way of doing it is fully to explain to the girls the reason for spinning and to place every facility for procuring khaddar at reasonable prices and of the type they need.
('37', 381, 3, 20, 839043) The teachers should also establish contact with the parents of the girls and secure their active co operation in the work.
('37', 381, 3, 21, 839166) The fact is that all this work can only be thoroughly done when the organizers
('37', 382, 0, 1, 839245) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 383
('37', 382, 1, 2, 839293) throw their whole soul into it, as witness the extraordinary success of the work among the Labour Union schools of Ahmedabad.
('37', 382, 1, 3, 839419) All the spinning teachers would do well to make themselves the improvised testing appliance which has been described in these pages.
('37', 382, 1, 4, 839552) Speed without strength is waste.
('37', 382, 1, 5, 839585) To draw thread is not enough.
('37', 382, 1, 6, 839615) It is necessary to draw thread that can be used for warp.
('37', 382, 1, 7, 839673) Young India, 9 12 1926
('37', 382, 2, 8, 839696) 115. KHADDAR IN THE PUNJAB
('37', 382, 3, 9, 839723) The following is a summary 1 prepared in the A.I.S.A. office of an exhaustive report in Hindi received from the A.I.S.A. agency, Punjab.
('37', 382, 3, 10, 839860) The original contains details which the summary has omitted for the sake of condensation.
('37', 382, 3, 11, 839950) In the original I find that khaddar work is going on in 42 centres.
('37', 382, 3, 12, 840018) I invite the reader to visualize what this means.
('37', 382, 3, 13, 840068) It means a living contact with toilers in these villages and distributing wealth among them in exchange for their labour.‘So do the merchants’ one may be thoughtlessly inclined to say.
('37', 382, 3, 14, 840253) But there is a great difference between a merchant who goes in their midst to exploit them and a patriot who goes to them to invite them to work and receive wages for their labour.
('37', 382, 3, 15, 840434) When the wheel is firmly established, its appeal will be irresistible.
('37', 382, 3, 16, 840505) Its result will be banishment of starvation for those who would work without having to tear down their homes.
('37', 382, 3, 17, 840615) The feature of the Punjab work is that it has now become almost self supporting.
('37', 382, 3, 18, 840696) It has practically no bad book debts.
('37', 382, 3, 19, 840734) Exchange of yarn for khaddar at an additional charge of 2 as.
('37', 382, 3, 20, 840796) per yard is a valuable feature fraught with great consequences.
('37', 382, 3, 21, 840860) It is possible, I suppose, only in a place like the Punjab where, as the report says there is a large number of men and women still wearing khaddar.
('37', 382, 3, 22, 841009) Lala Kishan Chand Bhatia naturally takes pride in the fact that he has been able to have sheets locally printed at reduced prices.
('37', 382, 3, 23, 841140) He has also imported the Khadi Pratishthan wheel and copied it with effect.
('37', 382, 3, 24, 841216) The cry in the Punjab as elsewhere is want of patronage.
('37', 382, 3, 25, 841273) Khaddar cannot be sold as fast as it is produced.
('37', 382, 3, 26, 841323) All may not die for the country, may we not for its sake even wear khaddar unless it is equal in appearance and price to the latest machine made stuff from Manchester or Japan?
('37', 382, 3, 27, 841500) If we will not even give one extra pice for khaddar or put some restraint upon our sartorial taste, What is our patriotism worth?
('37', 382, 4, 28, 841630) 1 Not reproduced here
('37', 383, 0, 1, 841652) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 383, 1, 2, 841694) Punjab has cotton, spinning, weaving and commercial ability.
('37', 383, 1, 3, 841755) Will it not have enough patriotism to buy up khaddar as fast as it can be made?
('37', 383, 1, 4, 841835) It should not be necessary for Jamnalalji or me or any one else to go to the Punjab, collect money for khaddar work or to sell it.

('37', 383, 2, 6, 841989) 116. DOWN WITH SUPERNATURALISM!
('37', 383, 3, 7, 842021) To THE EDITOR, Young India
('37', 383, 4, 8, 842048) SIR, When you judge the action of a ‘believer’ like Aurangzeb in desecrating and demolishing a place of worship like the Kashi temple as ‘belying’ his ‘belief’, viz., Islam (in Young India of 4 11 ’26), are you not presuming to know more of Islam than the Prophet of Islam himself?
('37', 383, 4, 9, 842330) For you must know that Mahomed himself, the beau ideal of Aurangzeb, when he entered Mecca in triumph against the enemies, destroyed all the objects and places of ‘idolatrous’ worship in that city, leaving a few of them like the Kaaba stone which he himself believed in!
('37', 383, 4, 10, 842601) So then you must either (i) say that Mahomed was one of those ‘so called believers who belied 2 their belief’,—which will not be in keeping with your former dictum that the great religious teachers of mankind were men who had exhibited the image of God in their own persons (vide Young India, 8 7 ’26, page 244, column 2); or (ii) allegorize away the iconoclastic career of the Arabian Prophet (May peace be on Him!), as you usually do with whatever in the scriptures of any sect taken literally you do not ‘understand’ or whatever in them similarly understood does not ‘appeal to your reason’; or (iii) repudiate the universally received life story of Mahomed as spurious.
('37', 383, 4, 11, 843275) If there is a fourth way, please point it out; but please remember that Aurangzeb has been styled a ‘living saint’ (Zinda Pir, etc.) by all Sunni divines and historians who have never a word to say against his temple destruction, so far as I know, but many of whom on the contrary have glorified him therefor.
('37', 383, 4, 12, 843585) Is this fact not remarkable, seeing how the Ulema of India are today divided on the subject of the desecrations, the demolitions and messacres which Ibn Saud, the Wahabi, has been responsible for in Mecca, Medina and Taif, one section (the Ahle hadis) Justifying those deeds as quite Islamic, and the other (Shias, Hanafis, etc.) declaring them un Islamic?
('37', 383, 4, 13, 843942) But I have yet to meet a member of that learned and pious fraternity who will wholeheartedly condemn Aurangzeb’s high handedness on the Hindus’ holiest of holies.
('37', 383, 4, 14, 844105) It is much like those Sanatanis who would lynch you for trying to do away with
('37', 383, 5, 15, 844184) 1 This appeared in the correspondence column of Young India.
('37', 383, 5, 16, 844245) 2 The source has “believed in” which was corrected in Young India, 23 12 1926.
('37', 384, 0, 1, 844324) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 385
('37', 384, 1, 2, 844372) untouchability in India and at the same time lynch also, if they could, those white coloured folk in South Africa who are maintaining untouchability with the Indians there.
('37', 384, 1, 3, 844545) I am thus led to think that conflict and inconsistency are in the nature of all non rational faiths of supernatural pretensions.
('37', 384, 1, 4, 844674) Hence, however much you try to ‘liberalize’ such religions, you will never have truly liberalized them before you have improved them out of existence altogether.
('37', 384, 1, 5, 844836) To mend them is to end them, and can only one liberalize them away; that is my opinion in which, the more I think, the more I am confirmed.
('37', 384, 1, 6, 844976) Prince Yudhishthira seems to have glimpsed the truth when he answered the Yaksha in this wise:
('37', 384, 2, 7, 845071) So in the cave where it lives we will do best to leave it!
('37', 384, 2, 8, 845130) Yours, etc.,
('37', 384, 3, 9, 845143) A SEEKER AFTER TRUTH The reader will be glad to have this beautiful letter.
('37', 384, 3, 10, 845219) The writer’s hit at me is quite delicious.
('37', 384, 3, 11, 845262) But I do not propose to adopt any of the three courses he thinks I usually take for defending the indefensible.
('37', 384, 3, 12, 845374) There is so far as I know nothing in common between the Prophet’s destruction of idols in Mecca and the reputed destruction by Aurangzeb.
('37', 384, 3, 13, 845512) And should it turn out that the Prophet had erred on occasions, his error would but prove his fallible nature without in any way diminishing his glory as an inspired seer exhibiting on most occasions the image of God?
('37', 384, 3, 14, 845730) He never himself claimed infallibility.
('37', 384, 3, 15, 845770) On the contrary, he often consulted his companions and when he was once told by Omer that he need not consult anybody as he had direct dealings with God, it is recorded that he retorted that if he had on that occasion a message from God, he would not have consulted Omer.
('37', 384, 3, 16, 846042) I know that “A Seeker after Truth” does not seriously mean that I “allegorize away”, without good cause, whatever is inconvenient.
('37', 384, 3, 17, 846173) I hope that his banter is meant merely to ‘draw me’.
('37', 384, 3, 18, 846226) Whatever the cause, I assure him and all concerned that whenever I regard any narrative as an allegory, I have substantial and intrinsic evidence for my belief.
('37', 384, 3, 19, 846387) Nor do I repudiate without sufficient cause anything as spurious or apocryphal.
('37', 384, 3, 20, 846467) As a fellow seeker after Truth I hope I have courage enough to own my errors and limitations.
('37', 384, 3, 21, 846561) There are things in all religious books which baffle me.
('37', 384, 3, 22, 846618) I hope some day to have them
('37', 385, 0, 1, 846647) 386 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 385, 1, 2, 846689) made clear to me.
('37', 385, 1, 3, 846707) Till then, I cultivate humility, patience to wait.
('37', 385, 1, 4, 846758) Man need not know all.
('37', 385, 1, 5, 846781) The most serious part however of the writer’s letter is his repudiation of the supernatural.
('37', 385, 1, 6, 846874) I suggest to him that rationalists have as many conundrums and inconsistencies to account for as supernat uralists.
('37', 385, 1, 7, 846990) Is the uniform testimony of some of the purest and noblest men so much humbug and hallucination when they say that acco rding not to their belief, but experience, there is something beyond the senses?
('37', 385, 1, 8, 847191) Is it not an arrogant claim to lay down the law that there is nothing beyond the five senses?
('37', 385, 1, 9, 847285) Who does not feel that there are mysteries impenetrable by reason?
('37', 385, 1, 10, 847352) Do not the daily and so called sudden transformations of the character of those who worship in faith incontestably show that there are things that reason cannot understand or explain?
('37', 385, 1, 11, 847536) The celebrated verse quoted by the writer after all presents the difficulty of knowing dharma except through the heart.
('37', 385, 1, 12, 847656) And, after all, the author of the great book from which the verse has been taken was himself a believer in the supernatural.
('37', 385, 1, 13, 847781) The mystery of creation and death is itself a living demonstration of the supernatural.
('37', 385, 1, 14, 847869) It will be time enough to scoff at it when man has by his reason succeeded in creating life.

('37', 386, 2, 3, 848564) WARDHA, December 9, 1926
('37', 386, 3, 4, 848589) MY DEAR SHUAIB, The papers you sent me through Shankerlal about the Nigoi ground have been lying with me and in front of me all these long days.
('37', 386, 3, 5, 848734) I have now read the whole of the thing carefully.
('37', 386, 3, 6, 848784) The minutes of the meeting of the arbitrators, or whatever they may be called, have not been signed by all the parties.
('37', 386, 3, 7, 848904) Messrs Bhopatkar and Dandekar were, therefore, strictly speaking, justified in making any corrections they chose.
('37', 386, 3, 8, 849018) I am not going into the merits at all.
('37', 386, 3, 9, 849057) Nor are the correc tions made, I think, vitally different from the context.
('37', 386, 3, 10, 849133) So far as I can see there is only one material correction, namely, ‘Hindus should ever have access to it as before.’ Is that not contemplated by the original draft?
('37', 386, 3, 11, 849298) What is the cart track in clause 4 meant for?
('37', 386, 3, 12, 849344) Was it intended that the cart track will enable the people to visit Dehu but not so as to enable them also to visit the paduka?
('37', 386, 3, 13, 849472) Having gone so far as to retain the rights of Hindus to visit the paduka, everything else becomes, in my opinion, of little consequence.
('37', 386, 3, 14, 849609) If you are interesting yourself in this matter, I would advise you carefully to study the documents and then guide the trustees.
('37', 386, 3, 15, 849738) If the Hindu arbitrators are still agreeable to the substance of the understa nding set forth in D, I think that there is every prospect of a settlement.
('37', 386, 3, 16, 849892) What are you now doing?
('37', 386, 3, 17, 849916) Do you propose to discharge the burden you have taken on your shoulders on behalf of the All India Spinners’ Association?
('37', 386, 3, 18, 850038) You have to render an account of your doings in that behalf to the President and, what is more, to the still small voice within.

('37', 395, 11, 15, 863122) AS AT THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, December 10, 1926
('37', 395, 12, 16, 863169) DEAR FRIEND, I wonder what is going on about the contemplated Chinese visit.
('37', 395, 13, 17, 863246) The Indian programme before me for the next year is so heavy and there are many other such considerations that I should now like to know definitely, at the earliest possible moment, if and when I must go to China.
('37', 395, 13, 18, 863460) You will please make it clear to the friends who are in correspondence with you that they are in no way bound to carry out visit programme, because they have contemplated it and have in a way
('37', 395, 14, 19, 863652) 1 Srinivasa Iyengar had been elected President of the Congress session due to be held at Gauhati.

('37', 396, 1, 2, 863930) even given me the invitation.
('37', 396, 1, 3, 863960) The visit, therefore, should be brought about only if there is a real felt want.

('37', 396, 1, 5, 864082) I have no desire for making speeches.
('37', 396, 1, 6, 864120) The only thing I love is simple heart to heart conversation and an elucidation of difficulties.

('37', 399, 5, 9, 869458) 138. KATHIAWAR POLITICAL CONFERENCE
('37', 399, 6, 10, 869494) I congratulate the Committee of the Kathiawar Political Confer ence on choosing Shri Amritlal Thakkar as President of its forth coming session 2. Names of a number of luminaries in the political field had been suggested but when Amritlal Thakkar’s name came up, no one had anything to say against it.
('37', 399, 6, 11, 869795) As I understand it, the main consideration underlying this choice is that the president should be at least someone from Kathiawar and a man of character with a patriotic spirit.
('37', 399, 6, 12, 869973) Shri Amritlal Thakkar could easily stand this triple test and come out successful.
('37', 399, 6, 13, 870056) We cannot today find a worker who can excel Shri Amrit lal Thakkar in point of character; whether in Kathiawar, in Gujarat or in India.
('37', 399, 6, 14, 870192) His sacrifice for the sake of the country was perhaps earlier than that of all of us.
('37', 399, 6, 15, 870278) His devotion has brought credit to him and his country and it is difficult to compete with him in dedicated service.
('37', 399, 6, 16, 870395) Moreover, the field of activity which he selected for such service is as easy as it is difficult.
('37', 399, 6, 17, 870493) It is easy because there are only a few who take interest in serving the communities whom he has chosen to serve and so he achieves quick results.
('37', 399, 6, 18, 870640) It is difficult because if no results that startle the world are forthcoming, the raw or unseasoned workers would feel despondent.
('37', 399, 6, 19, 870771) But Amritlal became the priest to Dheds 3 and Bhangis and not being satisfied with it became the servant and friend of the Bhils 4.
('37', 399, 7, 20, 870903) 1Vide Appendix “Romain Rolland’s Letter to Gandhiji”.
('37', 399, 7, 21, 870957) 2 Which was to be held at Porbandar in March 1927 but could be held only in January 1928. 3 One of the communities traditionally regarded as untouchables 4 Aboriginal tribe in Gujarat and Central India
('37', 400, 0, 1, 871159) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 401
('37', 400, 1, 2, 871207) What will such a man do at a political conference?
('37', 400, 1, 3, 871258) This point did not occur to those who selected him; but it did to Amritlal Thakkar.
('37', 400, 1, 4, 871342) Taking me to task for allowing his name to come up for selection, he writes to me a letter whose summary is given below: 1
('37', 400, 2, 5, 871465) The fact that this question occurred to him points to the fine state of his mind.
('37', 400, 2, 6, 871547) But does he not know that nowadays the Political Conference has made it its business to serve the Antyajas and others?
('37', 400, 2, 7, 871666) Who can say that this service is not implied by and included in khadi?
('37', 400, 2, 8, 871737) Not only that, but the Conference this year has directly rendered no mean service to the Antyajas and others and has spent no small amount of money for them.
('37', 400, 2, 9, 871895) Thus the very activities which are dear to Shri Amritlal Thakkar constitute the present field of operation of the Conference.
('37', 400, 2, 10, 872021) Moreover, Amritlal Thakkar is the pioneer of khadi work in Kathiawar.
('37', 400, 2, 11, 872091) I do not, however, know whether his love of khadi or his faith in it is still the same as before.
('37', 400, 2, 12, 872189) He will most probably clarify this point at the Conference.
('37', 400, 2, 13, 872249) Now there remains politics.
('37', 400, 2, 14, 872277) In my opinion, there can be no conference or other politics outside of such constructive activities.
('37', 400, 2, 15, 872378) I have visualized the same for the whole of India.
('37', 400, 2, 16, 872429) If India leaves off the so called politics and plunges itself only in constructive activities and works with the devotion of a Thakkar, swaraj will be secured very easily.
('37', 400, 2, 17, 872601) Moreover, if I apply this principle to India I would naturally apply it in particular to Kathiawar.
('37', 400, 2, 18, 872701) This does not mean that no political work should be done in Kathiawar or outside it.
('37', 400, 2, 19, 872786) He who can only do political work and finds constructive activity futile will certainly plunge himself in politics alone.
('37', 400, 2, 20, 872908) We shall take the cue from them and follow them.
('37', 400, 2, 21, 872957) If we do not like their work, we shall allow them to go their way.
('37', 400, 2, 22, 873024) When they will see that none of us follows them, they will doubt the correctness of their way and will retrace their steps.
('37', 400, 2, 23, 873148) The Kathiawar Conference has taken of this golden way.
('37', 400, 2, 24, 873203) I hope the Conference will not deviate from that path.
('37', 400, 2, 25, 873258) I do not know of a single incident by reason of which the Conference should so deviate.
('37', 400, 2, 26, 873346) If we become good, alert, free from fear, become united—the ruler too will easily become good, alert, loving and friendly towards his subjects.
('37', 400, 2, 27, 873490) The divine rule “if one is good, “the world is good” is no mere popular saying but a truth.
('37', 400, 2, 28, 873582) “As the subjects so the ruler” is truer in
('37', 400, 3, 29, 873625) 1 Not translated here.
('37', 400, 3, 30, 873648) In the letter Thakkar had asked Gandhiji how he could fit in with politics when his field of work was with Dheds, Bhangis, Bhils, Kolis and others.
('37', 401, 0, 1, 873796) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 401, 1, 2, 873838) this democratic age than “as the ruler so the sudjects”.
('37', 401, 1, 3, 873895) Hence politics means a relationship among the people from the lowest to the highest strata and unity among all.
('37', 401, 1, 4, 874007) This unity is a sort of constructive work wherein there is need of mutual relationship for all.

('37', 401, 2, 24, 875559) 139. ANTYAJ DIRECTORY
('37', 401, 3, 25, 875581) The Antyaj Directory which has been brought out by Shri Amritlal Thakkar’s Antyaj Seva Mandal 2, has been purposely publis hed by me, word for word, in the Navajivan 3. I am afraid some of the readers must have got annoyed on seeing it, and those who were not annoyed might not have read it.
('37', 401, 3, 26, 875873) If both these classes of readers exist
('37', 401, 4, 27, 875912) 1 At the session held there in 1925 2 Association for service of untouchables 3 In its issues of November 7, 14, 21, 28 and December 5, 1926
('37', 402, 0, 1, 876053) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 403
('37', 402, 1, 2, 876101) then I would specifically recommend them to retrieve the previous issues and read the directory.
('37', 402, 1, 3, 876198) The reader will get some idea of the amount of hard work put in compiling this directory.
('37', 402, 1, 4, 876288) Investigations were made in 88 villages of the Anand taluk itself.
('37', 402, 1, 5, 876355) Such detailed investigation in each and every village demands the sacrifice of a great deal of time.
('37', 402, 1, 6, 876456) The facts found in the directory bring disgrace to those who follow Hindu dharma.
('37', 402, 1, 7, 876538) One who reads this directory will realize imme diately how much we have failed in our duty towards the Antyajas.
('37', 402, 1, 8, 876651) A stranger may well say that the people of the place where Antyajas cannot have an adequate supply of even drinking water do not know the barest elements of religion.
('37', 402, 1, 9, 876818) The reader will note that in most of the villages Christian missionaries have been active.
('37', 402, 1, 10, 876909) But this thing is as shameful for us as it is creditable to them.
('37', 402, 1, 11, 876975) The service that we are now rendering to the Harijans may well be considered as satisfactory in view of the fact that formerly we were doing nothing at all.
('37', 402, 1, 12, 877132) But it is a matter of shame for us as long as there is even a single village without a Hindu worker for the Harijan or without proper facilities of drinking water.
('37', 402, 1, 13, 877296) Shri Amritlal Thakkar assigned the work of this directory to Shri Parikshitlal 1. Shri Parikshitlal is a graduate of the Vidyapith.
('37', 402, 1, 14, 877428) This vast field is open for every graduate of the Vidyapith.
('37', 402, 1, 15, 877489) Service to the villages is true service to the nation, because the people of India live in the seven lacs of her villages.
('37', 402, 1, 16, 877612) India does not exist in her cities which are mere degraded images of Europe’s cities.
('37', 402, 1, 17, 877698) And those who have realized that the service of villages starts with khadi and the cause of the Antyajas have known almost everything there is to know.

('37', 403, 7, 11, 878519) Here are my answers to your questions: (1) The attempts at solving the Hindu Muslim question have not yet been successful.
('37', 403, 7, 12, 878642) It is a matter of time.
('37', 403, 7, 13, 878666) (2) I am unable to endorse any scheme of co operation with the British Government until the system is adequately changed, i.e., until military expenditure is very considerably reduced to the advantage of India and prohibitive tariff imposed upon all foreign cloth and until prohibition is declared.
('37', 403, 7, 14, 878965) I have no select material to send you but you can gather all the information on these points in the pages of Young India whose principal writings are now available in book form.

('37', 404, 6, 16, 880577) An innocent prisoner need not starve and, in my opinion, he does not lose his dignity by accepting maintenance money from his custodians.
('37', 404, 6, 17, 880715) But I do think that he may not take any thing beyond his bare sustenance.
('37', 404, 6, 18, 880789) But he need not stint himself to the extent of damaging his health or starving his relatives if the custodians pay him enough to enable him to support those who were depending upon him.
('37', 404, 6, 19, 880975) Thus, after all, the question of amount is a matter for each individual to settle for himself.
('37', 404, 6, 20, 881070) But I have no doubt whatsoever about the propriety of accepting maintenance money.

('37', 411, 9, 18, 893738) Mr. Andrews cables as follows from Pretoria:
('37', 411, 10, 19, 893783) Prayer day endorsed by Dutch Church nineteenth.
('37', 411, 10, 20, 893831) Hertzog receives delegates 1 seventeenth.
('37', 411, 10, 21, 893873) Then retires.
('37', 411, 10, 22, 893887) First session twentieth.
('37', 411, 10, 23, 893912) The endorsement of the prayer day by the Dutch reformed Church is a great step towards securing an atmosphere favouring a just solution of the dificult question.
('37', 411, 10, 24, 894074) The Dutch Church is a most con servative body in South Africa.
('37', 411, 10, 25, 894137) It has rarely taken a broad view of the Indian or the general colour question as it is called in South Africa.
('37', 411, 10, 26, 894248) The reception that is to take place on the seventeenth by General Hertzog of the delegates to the Conference is a step in recognition of
('37', 411, 11, 27, 894385) 1 The members of the Indian deputation who were visiting South Africa to discuss with the Union Government problems of South African Indians
('37', 412, 0, 1, 894526) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 413
('37', 412, 1, 2, 894574) the tremendous importance of the Conference and of the issues that are to be discussed by the Conference.
('37', 412, 1, 3, 894680) I hope that the Indian public will back wholeheartedly the noble effort of this single minded Englishman.
('37', 412, 1, 4, 894786) One may thoughtlessly say that it costs nothing to offer prayers and that the pressmen will announce that prayers were offered for the success of the mission at so many places.
('37', 412, 1, 5, 894963) But in reality, it is a most difficult thing that Mr. Andrews has asked us to do.
('37', 412, 1, 6, 895045) One can give of one’s possessions willingly or unwillingly or even for a show.
('37', 412, 1, 7, 895124) One may give unwilling intellectual assent to a proposition.
('37', 412, 1, 8, 895185) But there is no such thing as unwilling or showy heart co operation.
('37', 412, 1, 9, 895254) And what Mr. Andrews wants is heart co operation, for, prayer is nothing else but an intense longing of the heart.
('37', 412, 1, 10, 895369) You may express yourself through the lips; you may express yourself in the private closet or in public; but to be genuine, the expression must come from the deepest recesses of the heart.
('37', 412, 1, 11, 895557) Let those who can, that is those who believe in the cause of the Indians of South Africa and who believe in God and therefore in prayer, set apart some time on the nineteenth instant for the heart co operation with the Indian settlers of South Africa and invoke God’s blessings on the deliberations of the Conference.
('37', 412, 1, 12, 895875) If there is anybody in India who still does not know what the Indian cause in South Africa is, let him or her understand that the very existence of the Indians in South Africa is at stake.
('37', 412, 1, 13, 896064) Specifically, the Asiatic Bill 1 that was suspended during the last session of the Union Parliament and which will be subject matter of discussion is a bill which is so designed as to make it impossible for any self respecting Indian to remain in South Africa.
('37', 412, 1, 14, 896325) Let those who do not know the legal position of Indians in South Africa realize that they have practically no political status whatsoever within the Union.
('37', 412, 1, 15, 896481) They have no rights even of residence in Orangia except as domestic servants.
('37', 412, 1, 16, 896559) In many parts they cannot become owners of landed property.Throughout South Africa, the trading rights have been considerably curtailed and the administration of the existing legislation regarding trading rights is becoming more and more severe against Indian traders, even against those who are holders of trading licenses of long standing.
('37', 412, 1, 17, 896901) I say nothing about the social barriers that have been erected against them and consequent difficulties about freedom of travelling etc.
('37', 412, 1, 18, 897038) They have hardly any facility for the education of their children worth the name.
('37', 412, 1, 19, 897120) The position, therefore, it will be seen, is precarious enough as it is.
('37', 412, 2, 20, 897193) 1 The Class Areas Bill
('37', 413, 0, 1, 897216) 414 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 413, 1, 2, 897258) The Asiatic Bill if it is passed will put the finishing touch.
('37', 413, 1, 3, 897321) The Conference has been brought about after tremendous difficulties to ease the situation and to secure the barest justice for the Indian settler.

('37', 413, 2, 7, 897672) 153. NOTES
('37', 413, 3, 8, 897683) “PROSPEROUS” INDIA Mr. A. M. Samuel, Minister for Overseas Trade, is reported to have thus spoken to the Lincoln Chamber of Commerce:
('37', 413, 4, 9, 897817) India is our best customer.
('37', 413, 4, 10, 897845) She buys about £ 90,000,000 worth of goods from us a year, mostly manufactured goods of high finish containing a large amount of British labour.
('37', 413, 4, 11, 897990) Any increase of trade with India, therefore, would be welcome because by increasing the employment of labour we would be carrying out the main policy of the present Government, namely, the reduction of unemployment figures.
('37', 413, 5, 12, 898214) India bought from us immense quantities of iron and steel goods and railway material.
('37', 413, 5, 13, 898300) She was prosperous and had large sums with which to pur chase imported goods.
('37', 413, 5, 14, 898378) She only awaited a level of prices which would suit her views.
('37', 413, 5, 15, 898441) The credit of India stood very high, second only to the credit of Great Britain herself.
('37', 413, 5, 16, 898530) Many firms in the Lincoln district already possessed properly equipped sales and technical organizations in India, but the Government representatives in India asked firms to provide efficient and technical representation upon the spot.
('37', 413, 5, 17, 898766) The sale of highly complex machinery and plant called for an increased backing up by technical advisers, The salesman needed a technical adviser at his right hand always to assist him in obtaining contracts.
('37', 413, 5, 18, 898974) It was necessary that the British technical representatives should be in touch with the buying engineers in India to explain the details of the machines offered or sold.
('37', 413, 5, 19, 899144) We still supplied 80 per cent of the machinery imported into India, and most of the British firms had their own technical agents in India, but he still came across reports of Indian purchasing authorities complaining that they did not get the services from the British expert staffs that they desired.
('37', 413, 5, 20, 899446) They also complained that we did not maintain an adequate supply in India of stocks and spare parts.
('37', 413, 5, 21, 899547) As regards the Indian market for agricultural machinery, he knew that British firms had gone to great trouble and expense to develop this market without any considerable success.
('37', 413, 5, 22, 899726) The Indian Government, however, was striving to assist the Indian cultivator, and one of the best methods to do so
('37', 414, 0, 1, 899841) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 415
('37', 414, 1, 2, 899889) was to put better agricultural implements into his hands.
('37', 414, 1, 3, 899947) Agricultural and co operative credit departments were being set up in India to show the people how to use and repair modern implements and to assist them to purchase them.
('37', 414, 1, 4, 900119) There is no doubt that Mr. Samuel honestly believes that we are prosperous, and that it would add to our prosperity to buy all the machinery that England can manufacture, whether agricultural or otherwise, as also technical skill.
('37', 414, 1, 5, 900350) How far from truth both these state ments appear to us to be.
('37', 414, 1, 6, 900412) We know that India is not prosperous; that it is daily growing poorer, and some of us know also that the problem of poverty will never be solved by an indiscriminate importation of machinery and technical skill from England, or any other foreign land.
('37', 414, 1, 7, 900664) As Gokhale put it years ago, this kind of importation stunts our growth.
('37', 414, 1, 8, 900737) We become more and more hewers of wood and drawers of water.
('37', 414, 1, 9, 900798) What we need to do is to add to our capacity for labour with our hands and feet the necessary technical skill, so that we may devise our own machinery suitable to our requirements.
('37', 414, 1, 10, 900979) A slavish imitation of the West can but kill all initiative or skill and therefore the capacity for living with anything like decent comfort.
('37', 414, 1, 11, 901121) It is such speeches like Mr. Samuel’s which arouse suspicions about the object of Commissions like the Royal Agricultural Commission, as was recently adverted to in these pages.
('37', 414, 1, 12, 901299) Young India, 16 12 1926

('37', 414, 3, 15, 901448) 1 I now give below a similar report from the Khadi Pratishthan omitting the balance sheet, because the items that the reader would be interested in are included in the body of the report.

('37', 414, 3, 17, 901776) The reader will note that magic lantern lectures for popularizing khadi are a special feature introduced by the Khadi Pratishthan and are being now taken up in other parts of India.
('37', 414, 3, 18, 901958) The technical department is also a strong feature of the Pratishthan.
('37', 414, 3, 19, 902028) After considerable difficulty, the Pratishthan has secured its own premises, where extensive experiments are being carried on in dyeing and bleaching all of which makes khadi more attractive.

('37', 415, 1, 2, 902328) 155. LETTER TO SHIVABHAI PATEL
('37', 415, 2, 3, 902359) WARDHA, Thursday, December 16, 1926
('37', 415, 3, 4, 902395) BHAI SHIVABHAI, I have your letter.
('37', 415, 3, 5, 902431) There is no reason for you to worry.
('37', 415, 3, 6, 902468) Strictly speaking, I do regard a violation of the vow to have occurred, but our responsibility for that is slight.
('37', 415, 3, 7, 902583) You did not consciously desire that the thing should happen, and, therefore, no elaborate atonement is necessary.
('37', 415, 3, 8, 902697) Whenever you have an involuntary discharge in dreams, you should take light food or even forgo a meal the next day.
('37', 415, 3, 9, 902813) Or, when you become cons cious that it has occurred, you should get up and take a hip bath.
('37', 415, 3, 10, 902905) If this is not possible, you should clean the wet part, and repeat Rama nama.
('37', 415, 3, 11, 902983) This cleaning will be enough atonement.
('37', 415, 3, 12, 903023) What you should do depends on the state of your mind at the moment.
('37', 415, 3, 13, 903091) After cleaning yourself in this manner, you should not make yourself unhappy about the occurrence or brood over it.
('37', 415, 3, 14, 903207) If you have slipped either in regard to eating, reading, thinking or selecting your company, see that you do not commit a similar error in future.
('37', 415, 3, 15, 903354) Only a person who is completely free from desire can escape involuntary ejaculation, and that too with ceaseless effort.
('37', 415, 3, 16, 903475) You should give up your evening meals and casual snacks.
('37', 415, 3, 17, 903532) Nothing should be taken just to gratify the palate.
('37', 415, 3, 18, 903584) You should be content with whatever pleasure you get from the food that you must take.
('37', 415, 4, 19, 903671) Blessings from
('37', 415, 5, 20, 903686) BAPU [PS.] There is no news about your brother yet.
('37', 415, 5, 21, 903738) I have not gone through the letter after writing it.

('37', 423, 8, 25, 918229) 1 The reference in the letter to Gandhiji’s arrival on 23rd in Calcutta en route to Gauhati suggests that the letter was written on the preceding Monday, which fell on this date.

('37', 424, 1, 3, 918726) I am, if possible, more convinced than ever that swaraj is impossible to be attained if there is no Hindu Muslim unity, if we still suffer from the curse of untouchability and if our middle classes refuse to understand the gospel of swadeshi.
('37', 424, 1, 4, 918969) Don’t think that I am sticking on to this programme out of obstinacy or perversity.
('37', 424, 1, 5, 919053) There is nothing on earth that I would not give for the sake of the country excepting, of course, two things and two only, viz., Truth and Non violence.
('37', 424, 1, 6, 919206) I would not sacrifice these two for all the world.
('37', 424, 1, 7, 919257) For, to me Truth is God and there is no way to find truth except the way of Non violence.

('37', 424, 1, 9, 919414) For I know that a man who forsakes Truth can forsake his country, and his nearest and dearest ones.
('37', 424, 1, 10, 919514) Now is the time to act.
('37', 424, 1, 11, 919538) For how long is a man to go on talking?
('37', 424, 1, 12, 919578) He may do so once, twice, aye, a hundred times, but action or example is his last resort.
('37', 424, 1, 13, 919668) Even if the whole of India ranged on one side were to declare that Hindu Muslim unity is impossible, I will declare that it is perfectly possible, I will say that, if there is anything like God or Truth on earth, Hindu Muslim unity is also possible.
('37', 424, 1, 14, 919918) Even if masses of people were to burn khadi publicly and say that it is an insane programme, I will declare that those people have gone mad.
('37', 424, 1, 15, 920059) In the same way, even if all the Hindus of India were to be ranged against me in declaring that untouchability, as we know it today, has the sanction of the Shastras or the smritis, I will then declare that these Shastras and these smritis are false.
('37', 424, 1, 16, 920310) Everywhere shall I go forth thus uttering the three articles of my creed—my kalma and my gayatri,—so that I may be true to myself and my Maker.

('37', 426, 1, 2, 922566) we labour under the curse of child marriage, and so long as many members of our society are children of such marriages, so long much bodily exercise is an impossibility.
('37', 426, 1, 3, 922736) Who will recommend physical exercise to consumptives?
('37', 426, 1, 4, 922790) We should therefore lay the axe at the root of this curse, if we would see our young men and women strong and healthy and India on the path of vigorous and healthy growth.
('37', 426, 1, 5, 922962) Manu has laid down that a student should observe brahmacharya up to his 25th year at least.
('37', 426, 1, 6, 923054) All physical exercise will be futile so long as these conditions are not satisfied.
('37', 426, 1, 7, 923138) But there is another thing to which I should like to draw your attention.
('37', 426, 1, 8, 923212) You know that I am pledged to have nothing to do with things even remotely connected with violence.
('37', 426, 1, 9, 923312) Whatever others may say, I am convinced that the way of non violence is the only way and the highest and permanent religion for me.
('37', 426, 1, 10, 923444) How is it then, someone might ask, that an avowed votary of non violence like me has at all associated himself with an institution like this?
('37', 426, 1, 11, 923586) The reason is clear.
('37', 426, 1, 12, 923607) Ahimsa or non violence means the renunciation of the capacity to use violence.
('37', 426, 1, 13, 923686) He who has not that capacity is therefore incapable of exercising non violence.
('37', 426, 1, 14, 923766) Non violence is a mighty spiritual force but its votary should have the power to use physical force and should consciously and deliberately refuse to exercise that force.
('37', 426, 1, 15, 923937) Not that physical training is a sine qua non for acquiring capacity for violence, but we may not encourage our youths to have feeble physiques in order to be capable of ahimsa.
('37', 426, 1, 16, 924114) You cannot make a man non violent by depriving him of arms.
('37', 426, 1, 17, 924174) One of the many crimes of the British rule in India is that we have been forcibly deprived of our arms—not indeed with a view to making us non violent even if such a thing was possible but to emasculating us.
('37', 426, 1, 18, 924383) I want India to be strong and free to exercise its strength and yet to renounce it.
('37', 426, 1, 19, 924467) Thus I like institutions like these for physical training.
('37', 426, 1, 20, 924526) But let me utter a word of warning.
('37', 426, 1, 21, 924562) No institution that has as its object the subjection of a community, whether Hindu, Mussalman, Parsi, or Christian, can have my blessings.
('37', 426, 1, 22, 924701) Only that institution can have my blessings which aims as the growth of the physical culture of all communities, of all the youths of the nation, to whatever creed or community they belong.
('37', 426, 1, 23, 924891) I should not have come here, did I not know that the gymnasium I have opened belonged to the latter type, and whilst once more congratulating you I wish and pray that you may all

('37', 427, 1, 2, 925112) be true and pure, and your lives may be consecrated to the service of our nation and of our religions.

('37', 427, 6, 13, 925847) A friend thus writes: 2
('37', 427, 7, 14, 925871) We have more Gangas and Jumnas than the two.
('37', 427, 7, 15, 925916) It is true they bear other names.
('37', 427, 7, 16, 925950) They are, however, watering our vast plains from the North to the South and the East to the West.
('37', 427, 7, 17, 926048) The message that the Ganga and the Jumna gave to this friend is not the only message that the mighty rivers of India are giving to her inhabitants.
('37', 427, 7, 18, 926196) They remind us of the sacrifice we must make for the sake of the land we are living in.
('37', 427, 7, 19, 926284) They remind us of the process of purification that we must continuously go through as the rivers themselves are going through from moment to moment.
('37', 427, 7, 20, 926433) I wrote nearly 10 years ago that the gayatri, the common prayer of Hinduism, was one of the precious gifts of the Ganga.
('37', 427, 7, 21, 926554) Her shining waters must have given the rishis of old the inspiration.
('37', 427, 7, 22, 926624) In the modern rush, the chief use we have for our rivers is to empty our gutters in them and to navigate our cargo vessels, and in the process make them dirtier still.
('37', 427, 7, 23, 926792) We have no time, as the friend had, to stroll down to these rivers, and in silent meditation listen to the message they murmur to us.

('37', 428, 1, 2, 927224) 172. NOTES
('37', 428, 2, 3, 927235) A. I. S. A. RESOLUTIONS The following resolutions were passed by the Council of the All India Spinners’ Association at its meeting held at Wardha from 13th to 16th December 1926. I. Resolved that all sale depots conducted directly by the All India Spinners’ Association or through provincial departm ents be instructed strictly to avoid all sales on credit whether they be retail sales or wholesale transactions with other depots II.
('37', 428, 2, 4, 927669) Resolved that cash securities be insisted on from hawkers covering the amount of stock taken by them for sales.
('37', 428, 2, 5, 927781) In special cases, however, where desirable hawkers are unable to furnish such security, personal sureties may be taken from them.
('37', 428, 2, 6, 927911) In all cases hawkers should be strictly warned that they should make no credit sales on any account and periodical settlements of accounts should be made.
('37', 428, 2, 7, 928066) If at any time a hawker is unable to pay up the cash for the stock sold or the balance of stock does not tally, the hawker should be at once discharged and steps should be taken against him for recovery of the monies due.
('37', 428, 2, 8, 928288) whereas it is not desirable that the sale depots should be run in places where the public does not give adequate supp ort enabling them to be conducted without loss, all provincial departments are instructed to close down depots where, after two years’ experience, it is found that the charges incurred exceed 6 1/4% of the total sales effected per year, and to open new depots only where they expect this standard to be reached at least in the course of a year.
('37', 428, 2, 9, 928751) Whereas it is necessary, at present, to concentrate our efforts on such centres, where, by reason of greater unemploy ment or special adaptability to the industry of hand spinning and hand weaving, there are greater facilities for the production of khadi, it is resolved that, in proposing schemes of work, provincial agents and secretaries should not undertake to open or maintain centres of production which can be run only at a loss.
('37', 428, 2, 10, 929188) But where it is considered desirable in the interests of the movement that any centres should be run or maintained at a loss, it should be borne in mind that no more than 10% of the total capital invested for production in the province should be invested in such pioneer effort.
('37', 429, 0, 1, 929467) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 429, 1, 2, 929509) KENYA INDIANS In another column is published a letter from Mr. D. B. Desai, a settler of Kenya, referring to an increase in the poll tax which Indians of Kenya have been made to pay for the past twelve years and more.
('37', 429, 2, 3, 929727) The letter is remarkable for the wealth of details it contains.
('37', 429, 2, 4, 929791) If the facts set forth in it are true, it is a serious reflection upon the Europeans of Kenya and the Kenya Government.
('37', 429, 2, 5, 929911) The reader will recollect that the Indians of Kenya did not submit to the poll tax without protest.
('37', 429, 2, 6, 930011) Of course the protest was useless.
('37', 429, 2, 7, 930046) But one would have thought that there would be no further addition to the iniquitous tax.
('37', 429, 2, 8, 930136) If, however, my correspondent is right, by a currency trick the tax wasraised by 50 per cent., i.e., it went up from 20 shillings to 30 and now the amending legislation raises it to 50 shillings.
('37', 429, 2, 9, 930332) The reasons given for the rise would seem to be utterly absurd.
('37', 429, 2, 10, 930396) The reader must read the letter to know how the tax is to be utilized.
('37', 429, 2, 11, 930467) The Kenya Indians have certainly every reason for hoping that the public and the Government will come to their assistance and demand a veto of this discriminating and unjust legislation.
('37', 429, 2, 12, 930654) Young India, 23 12 1926
('37', 429, 3, 13, 930678) 173. KHADI SERVICE
('37', 429, 4, 14, 930697) The Council of the All India Spinners’ Association, after most careful and exhaustive discussion and after considering all the opinions that had been received upon the draft published some time ago in these pages, has recast the rules which the reader will find published elsewhere.
('37', 429, 4, 15, 930980) Forms of application and contract of service are also published.
('37', 429, 4, 16, 931045) This service provides those who want to serve the cause of khadi an opportunity of so doing and, at the same time, a modest remuneration for themselves.
('37', 429, 4, 17, 931198) The Board of Studies will also be the Examination Board.
('37', 429, 4, 18, 931255) It does not mean necessarily that all the Examiners will examine all the candidates.
('37', 429, 4, 19, 931340) But the various examinations required under the rules will be conducted by one or more of the examiners selected by the Chairman of the Board.
('37', 429, 4, 20, 931483) Suggestions were received that the course which extends to 3 years is altogether too long for the remuneration promised.
('37', 429, 4, 21, 931604) But all the
('37', 429, 5, 22, 931616) 1 For the text of the letter, vide Appendix “Kenya Indians: D.B. Desai’s Letter”, 12 12 1926
('37', 430, 0, 1, 931709) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 431
('37', 430, 1, 2, 931757) members came to the conculsion that 3 years were none too long for the subjects to be studied and the practical work to be done.
('37', 430, 1, 3, 931886) Experience gained during the last five years has shown that continued practice is necessary to learn the various arts that are included in the course.
('37', 430, 1, 4, 932037) Those who have gone out to organize khadi work in the different villages with less experience and knowledge have found themselves handicapped.
('37', 430, 1, 5, 932180) The science of hand spinning is capable of progressive improvement.
('37', 430, 1, 6, 932248) Researches that are being made from time to time show that there is room for the best among us to apply themselves to the development of the art so that without extra effort or time the income of the millions, for whom hand spinning is designed, may be almost doubled.
('37', 430, 1, 7, 932517) It is an unfortunate fact that in our schools and colleges handic rafts find no place.
('37', 430, 1, 8, 932604) All the knowledge, therefore, gained in the schools and colleges is of little use for the training required for khadi service.
('37', 430, 1, 9, 932731) Therefore a graduate has to start almost on equal terms with a raw youth.
('37', 430, 1, 10, 932805) Indeed, it is possible for the former even to labour under a handicap, if he has developed, as many do develop, a repugnance towards physical exertion.
('37', 430, 1, 11, 932957) The second question that came up for anxious consideration was that of remuneration.
('37', 430, 1, 12, 933042) The Khadi Service is designed for meeting the need of paupers.
('37', 430, 1, 13, 933105) It is impossible to hold out bright pecuniary prospects in such a service.
('37', 430, 1, 14, 933180) I have no doubt whatsoever that the scale of salaries devised by the Government is out of all proportion to the condition of India’s masses.
('37', 430, 1, 15, 933321) It has relation to the requirements of the inhabitants of a rich island and therefore means an almost unbearable burden upon the poor millions.
('37', 430, 1, 16, 933465) Let no one, therefore, compare the remuneration offered under the Khadi Service with that obtainable under the Government service.
('37', 430, 1, 17, 933596) At the same time, I make bold to say that the start offered is as good as that offered by the Government.
('37', 430, 1, 18, 933702) Where the Khadi Service fails in comparison is in the ultimate prospect.
('37', 430, 1, 19, 933775) The maximum attainable under the Government may reach four figures whereas Khadi Service offers an increase amounting to Rs. 20 at the most.
('37', 430, 1, 20, 933916) For those, therefore, who have received an English education to enter this service is undoubtedly a sacrifice.
('37', 430, 1, 21, 934027) But is it too much to ask the English educated youths of the country to make what after all is a very small sacrifice?
('37', 430, 1, 22, 934146) I consider it to be very small, for it should be remembered that they have received their English education at the expense of the masses.
('37', 430, 1, 23, 934284) It is an exclusive education which the masses can never get.
('37', 430, 1, 24, 934345) And it is an education which, if it has given us a few self sacrificing patriots, has also produced many more men who
('37', 431, 0, 1, 934463) 432 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 431, 1, 2, 934505) have been willing accomplices with the Government in holding India in bondage.
('37', 431, 1, 3, 934584) It will also be noted that to the poor and deserving, the service offers a suitable scholarship and at the end of the training, while the rules bind the Association to keep those who may be found properly qualified employed for 10 years, they leave it open for them to serve the Association or to seek prospects elsewhere.
