('37', 431, 2, 6, 935098) 174. HAND WEAVING AMONG PARSIS A correspondent extracts for me the following passage from the Gazetteer of the Bombay Presidency, Volume VII, Page 155, edition 1883:
('37', 431, 3, 7, 935264) The Parsi weavers of Gandevi were of special note, and in 1787 88 Dr. Hove, a European traveller, visited that town for the express purpose of learning from the Parsis some knowledge of their art.
('37', 431, 3, 8, 935461) The industry has died out for above fifty years.
('37', 431, 3, 9, 935510) The Parsi women of the priestly class still, however, make a large number of sacred threads kusti or kasti, worn by Parsi men and women.
('37', 431, 3, 10, 935647) These find a large sale in Bombay and cost Rs. 3 or more according to the labour displayed.
('37', 431, 3, 11, 935739) Some of the Parsi women also make tape for cots and rough dhoti and khadi to order for local traders, but the Parsis as a rule have quite abandoned the weaving in which they excelled.
('37', 431, 3, 12, 935923) What a great boon to India and to themselves it would be if the Parsis who are conducting liquor shops were to exchange the immoral liquor traffic for the uplifting and productive occupation of weaving in which they excelled only 50 years ago!
('37', 431, 3, 13, 936167) The reference to the hand spun kasti reminds me of the stalwart Parsi sister whom I met in Navsari and who told me that the Parsi ladies of Navsari who made their livelihood out of kasti spinning and whose sacred fingers gave the religious touch to the kasti were hounded out by those who had gone there under the guise of reformers to substitute the hand spun thread with the machine spun.

('37', 441, 2, 5, 959281) 183. RESOLUTION AND SPEECH AT CONGRESS SESSION, GAUHATI 1
('37', 441, 3, 6, 959339) December 26, 1926 RESOLUTION This Congress expresses its horror and indignation at the cowardly and treacherous murder of Swami Shraddhanand and places on record its sense of the irreparable loss the nation has sus tained by the tragic death of a brave and noble patriot who dedicated his life and his great gifts to the service of his country and of his faith and espoused with fearless devotion the cause of the lowly, the fallen and the weak.
('37', 441, 4, 7, 959785) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('37', 441, 5, 8, 959807) You must have noticed that the resolution I have moved originally stood in Maulana Mohamed Ali’s name.
('37', 441, 5, 9, 959910) But I am here to move it in obedience to the President’s summons.
('37', 441, 5, 10, 959976) We see from the newspapers that the assassination of Swamiji has evoked grief and horror throughout the land.
('37', 441, 5, 11, 960086) I said speaking on the same subject at the All India Congress Committee that we should not mourn over Swamiji’s death.
('37', 441, 5, 12, 960205) He had died the death of a hero, and every one of us might wish for such a death.
('37', 441, 5, 13, 960287) But I want to make a slight correction in that last statement.
('37', 441, 5, 14, 960350) Every brave man welcomes such a death whenever it comes to him.
('37', 441, 5, 15, 960414) He greets it as a friend.
('37', 441, 5, 16, 960440) But let no one therefore invite or hanker after such a death, let no one desire that someone else should be in the wrong and err against God and man, so that he might become a martyr.
('37', 441, 5, 17, 960624) It is wrong to wish anyone to go astray.
('37', 441, 5, 18, 960665) Let us all be brave enough to die the death of a martyr, but let no one lust for martyrdom.
('37', 441, 5, 19, 960757) Swamiji was a hero among heroes, the bravest of the brave.
('37', 441, 5, 20, 960816) He had astonished the nation with an unbroken record of bravery.
('37', 441, 5, 21, 960881) I am witness of the pledge he had taken to sacrifice himself at the altar of the country.
('37', 441, 5, 22, 960971) But need anyone speak at length on Swamiji’s services to the nation?
('37', 441, 5, 23, 961040) Swamiji, as everyone knew, was the help of the helpless, the
('37', 441, 6, 24, 961101) 1 The text of the speech was also published in Young India, 13 1 1927, under the heading “Hero among Heroes”.
('37', 442, 0, 1, 961211) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 443
('37', 442, 1, 2, 961259) friend of the weak and the oppressed and the work he had done for the untouchables was unsurpassed.
('37', 442, 1, 3, 961359) I well remember his having told me once that, unless every Hindu member of the All India Congress Committee had an untouchable servant in his home, the work of the Congress for the uplift of the untouchables would not be complete.
('37', 442, 1, 4, 961590) This may sound as an impracticable proposal, but it shows his unbounded love for the untouchables.
('37', 442, 1, 5, 961689) I shall not refer here to his many other services.
('37', 442, 1, 6, 961740) Whilst the assassination of such a great hero and patriot, such a servant and devotee of God as Swamiji, can be made to serve the country’s cause, imperfect men as we are, it is natural for us to mourn over his sad death.
('37', 442, 1, 7, 961962) And when one thinks of the circumstances under which he met his death, one is naturally filled with horror and indignation.
('37', 442, 1, 8, 962086) The assassin sought an interview with Swamiji to have a discussion on Islam.
('37', 442, 1, 9, 962163) His faithful servant refused to admit him as he had Dr. Ansari’s orders to allow no interviews so long as Swamiji was seriously ailing.
('37', 442, 1, 10, 962299) But God had evidently ordered otherwise.
('37', 442, 1, 11, 962340) Swamiji, when he overheard the request, asked Dharam Singh to let the man in.
('37', 442, 1, 12, 962418) Brother Abdul Rashid was shown in.
('37', 442, 1, 13, 962453) I purposely call him brother, and if we are true Hindus you will understand why I call him so.
('37', 442, 1, 14, 962548) Swamiji asked his servant to admit Abdul Rashid, because God had willed to show therethrough the greatness of Swamiji and the glory of Hinduism.
('37', 442, 1, 15, 962693) Swamiji was, of course, too ill to discuss religious topics and he asked the stranger to seek another occasion.
('37', 442, 1, 16, 962805) But he would not go.
('37', 442, 1, 17, 962826) He said he was thirsty and asked for water.
('37', 442, 1, 18, 962870) Swamiji asked Dharam Singh to fetch water for him and taking advantage of his absence, the man deposited bullet shots in Swamiji’s breast.
('37', 442, 1, 19, 963009) This is a thing which should not have happened in India—India where both Hindus and Mussalmans are proud of their faiths.
('37', 442, 1, 20, 963131) I have studied the Koran with the same reverent attention as I give the Gita, and I say that the Koran nowhere sanctions or enjoins such murders.
('37', 442, 1, 21, 963277) The murder has been possible because the two communities look upon each other with feelings of hatred and enmity.
('37', 442, 1, 22, 963391) Many Mussalmans believe that Lalaji and Malaviyaji are the sworn enemies of Islam as was Swamiji in their opinion.
('37', 442, 1, 23, 963506) On the other hand, many Hindus regard Sir Abdur Rahim and other Mussalmans as the enemies of Hinduism.
('37', 442, 1, 24, 963609) To my mind both are wholly wrong.
('37', 442, 1, 25, 963643) Swamiji was no enemy of Islam nor are Lalaji and Malaviyaji.
('37', 442, 1, 26, 963704) Lalaji and Malaviyaji have a right to express their opinion freely and even if we disagree with them, no one may excite feelings of hatred against them.
('37', 442, 1, 27, 963857) And yet, what do we see today?
('37', 442, 1, 28, 963888) There are few Mussalman papers today which do not use foul language against these patriots.
('37', 442, 1, 29, 963980) Now I ask in all humility what is the wrong they have done.
('37', 442, 1, 30, 964040) We may not see eye to eye
('37', 443, 0, 1, 964066) 444 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 443, 1, 2, 964108) with them in their methods of work.
('37', 443, 1, 3, 964144) But I am sure that it is his great service that has earned for Malaviyaji the name, Bharat Bhushan.
('37', 443, 1, 4, 964244) Lalaji too has a great record of service.
('37', 443, 1, 5, 964286) Then take the Mussalman leaders.
('37', 443, 1, 6, 964319) Sir Abdur Rahim may think that Hindus are in advance of the Mussalmans in every respect, that they are rich, they are educated, and the Mussalmans are poor and uneducated.
('37', 443, 1, 7, 964491) Sir Abdur Rahim thinks that his community should have a preference in the services.
('37', 443, 1, 8, 964575) It is open to us to feel and say that he is mistaken in his views, but why should we abuse him for his opinions?
('37', 443, 1, 9, 964688) If Maulana Mahomed Ali says that although he has respect for Gandhi he holds that the faith of a Muslim who believes in the Koran is greater than the faith of Gandhi, why should we be angry?
('37', 443, 1, 10, 964879) Do not some Christian clergymen say that a Christian regularly going to church and serving Jesus is better than a Hindu however pious he may be?

('37', 443, 1, 12, 965053) I therefore appeal to you that if you hold dear the memory of Swami Shraddhanandji, you would help in purging the atmosphere of mutual hatred and calumny, you would help in boycotting papers which foment hatred and spread misrepresentation.
('37', 443, 1, 13, 965294) I am sure that India would lose nothing if 90 per cent of the papers were to cease today.
('37', 443, 1, 14, 965384) Many Mussalman papers today subsist on hatred of the Hindu and many Hindu papers subsist on hatred of the Mussalman.
('37', 443, 1, 15, 965501) Swamiji has left for us a rich lesson written in his blood.
('37', 443, 1, 16, 965561) “Do you know the liberality of the Arya Samaj?,” he once asked me.
('37', 443, 1, 17, 965628) “Do you know how Maharshi Dayanand forgave the man who poisoned him?” I knew it.
('37', 443, 1, 18, 965709) How could I be ignorant of it, knowing as I did that the Maharshi had before him the example of Yudhishthira and the teaching of the Gita and the Upanishads?
('37', 443, 1, 19, 965867) But Shraddhanandji in his overflowing reverence for the Maharshi dilated upon his forgiveness.
('37', 443, 1, 20, 965962) I tell you the disciple had no less of that noble quality than his great master.
('37', 443, 1, 21, 966043) Speaking once about the implications of shuddhi he told me that his shuddhi excluded any feeling of ill will for the Mussalman, that it meant purification of self and of the great community to which he belonged, and that his ideal was the ideal of the Gita—“See thyself in every one of the created beings.” But he emphasized that the Hindu also was no less a friend of his than the Mussalman and that it was his duty to serve him.
('37', 443, 1, 22, 966474) Even if the whole Muslim world were to turn against me, I would declare that Malaviyaji is my friend and elder brother.
('37', 443, 1, 23, 966594) I declare also in the same breath that none of the Mussalman leaders is an enemy of Hinduism.
('37', 443, 1, 24, 966688) Sir Abdur Rahim is not an enemy of the Hindus, nor is Mian Fazli Hussain.
('37', 443, 1, 25, 966762) When I met him he assured me that he was an old Congressman, that he loved the Hindus no less than the Mussalmans, but that as a Mussalman he wanted to serve the latter.
('37', 443, 1, 26, 966932) We may disagree with him in his views, we may not like his
('37', 444, 0, 1, 966991) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 445
('37', 444, 1, 2, 967039) demands for the Mussalmans, but why should we therefore swear at him and say that he is an enemy of the Hindus?
('37', 444, 1, 3, 967151) Why should we not express our dissent from his views and fight them, if necessary, even as I do with Malaviyaji, in many respects, in a satyagrahi way?
('37', 444, 1, 4, 967303) I repeat, therefore, with all the emphasis I can command that Sir Abdur Rahim or Mr. Jinnah or the Ali Brothers are no enemies of the Hindus.
('37', 444, 1, 5, 967445) Let not the lesson of Swami Shraddhanandji’s death be lost on us.

('37', 445, 1, 2, 969811) 184. RESOLUTION AND SPEECH AT CONGRESS SESSION, GAUHATI
('37', 445, 2, 3, 969867) December 26, 1926 RESOLUTION This Congress welcomes the Round Table Conference now sitting in South Africa to deliberate upon the best method of dealing with the question of the status of Indian settlers in that sub continent and prays for divine blessing and guidance upon its deliberations.
('37', 445, 2, 4, 970160) This Congress once more tenders its thanks to that good Englishman, Mr. C. F. Andrews, who has been chiefly instru mental in preparing in South Africa a calm atmosphere suitable for the holding of the Conference.
('37', 445, 2, 5, 970373) This Congress authorizes the President to cable the text of the Resolution to General Hertzog, Sir M. Habibulla and Mr. C. F. Andrews.
('37', 445, 3, 6, 970508) Mahatmaji addressed the assembly in Hindi and the following is a summary of his speech: He said that Mr. C. F. Andrews had kept him in touch with the position in South Africa through correspondence.
('37', 445, 3, 7, 970707) Mr. Andrews had emphasized in his letters that prayers should be held all over for divine guidance of the Round Table Conference.
('37', 445, 3, 8, 970837) Need for such prayer was paramount.
('37', 445, 3, 9, 970873) They knew that the Indian Government had no power to force its will on South Africa.
('37', 445, 3, 10, 970958) The recent Imperial Conference had conceded to the dominions even greater freedom and independence in the field of imperial relations.
('37', 445, 3, 11, 971093) They could, therefore, only pray to God to shower His blessings on those engaged in the discussions of the Round Table Conference so that enlightened by the divine blessings, the Conference might concede justice to the Indian settlers in South Africa.
('37', 445, 3, 12, 971345) He then drew the attention of the audience to the fact that the untouchability of South Africa, from which their countrymen were suffering, was nothing but a repercussion of Indian untouchability.
('37', 445, 3, 13, 971542) It therefore behoved them to put their own house in order.
('37', 445, 3, 14, 971601) He reminded the South African statesmen that history showed those who having power abused it prepared for their own ruin, and implored them to grant the Indian settlers elementary justice which they desired.
('37', 445, 3, 15, 971809) They did not ask for favours; in fact they had forgone, for the sake of peace, things they need not have in strict justice.
('37', 445, 3, 16, 971933) Report of the Indian National Congress, Forty first Session, Gauhati (Assam), 1926, pp.

('37', 446, 1, 2, 972143) 185. LETTER TO ASHRAM WOMEN
('37', 446, 2, 3, 972171) GAUHATI, Monday, December 27, 1926
('37', 446, 3, 4, 972206) DEAR SISTERS, Instead of writing to you in the morning as usual, I am writing this just before the mail is cleared.
('37', 446, 3, 5, 972322) Here it is cleared early.
('37', 446, 3, 6, 972348) The scenery around here is lovely.
('37', 446, 3, 7, 972383) Our hut is put up right on the bank of the Brahmaputra; Kaka Saheb would be tempted by the very sight of the hut to stay here.
('37', 446, 3, 8, 972510) There is a thatch of straw by way of roof.
('37', 446, 3, 9, 972553) The walls are made of pieces of bamboo that grows all round here.
('37', 446, 3, 10, 972619) The bamboo is plastered with mud.
('37', 446, 3, 11, 972653) The inside of the wall is covered with khadi made in Assam.
('37', 446, 3, 12, 972713) There is no cot inside, but there is an improvised platform, a wooden plank with bamboo legs.
('37', 446, 3, 13, 972807) Over it is spread straw, on the hay a carpet and on the carpet a khadi sheet.
('37', 446, 3, 14, 972885) On this I sit, dine and sleep.
('37', 446, 3, 15, 972916) It is big enough to accommodate four more, but no one else sleeps on it.
('37', 446, 3, 16, 972989) The ground in the hut, too, is spread over with hay, on which is spread a carpet, which again is covered with khadi.
('37', 446, 3, 17, 973106) Who would not like to stay in such a hut?
('37', 446, 3, 18, 973148) Of course, the life of such a hut is very short.
('37', 446, 3, 19, 973197) It is useless in the rainy season.
('37', 446, 3, 20, 973232) But it costs very little, takes only a day or two to put up, and requires no great skill.
('37', 446, 3, 21, 973322) This is so with all true art.
('37', 446, 3, 22, 973352) It is always simple and natural.
('37', 446, 3, 23, 973385) It is quite damp and cold here, but if one moves about briskly one does not get ill.
('37', 446, 3, 24, 973470) More next time, whatever comes to my mind then.
('37', 446, 3, 25, 973518) Blessings from BAPU

('37', 447, 3, 4, 973686) Mr. Gandhi said an appeal had been made to him for sense of justice.
('37', 447, 3, 5, 973755) His sense of justice would restore the yarn franchise and make spinning also obligatory.
('37', 447, 4, 6, 973844) Personally he believed in quality rather than in quantity, but if Congressmen believed in quantity rather than in quality, he suggested that the fewer the restrictions the better for the Congress.
('37', 447, 4, 7, 974041) If, on the other hand, they believed in quality, then they must impose certain restrictions upon membership which promoted quality and thereby promoted national regeneration.
('37', 447, 4, 8, 974216) The Congress wanted all the parties within its fold, but they wanted them not at any cost, and let it not be a charge either against the No changers or against the Swarajists that they wanted to keep the Congress as a close corporation; but, after all, national organizations had their own restrictions which regulated their growth.
('37', 447, 4, 9, 974549) It was, therefore, for the committee to decide whether khaddar was essential or not.
('37', 447, 4, 10, 974634) In his opinion it was the only binding tie between the Congress and the masses.
('37', 447, 4, 11, 974714) There were on the Spinners’ Association’s register more than fifty thousand men and women who were provided with work.
('37', 447, 4, 12, 974833) Congress must harness this power of khaddar and increase it in order to achieve swaraj.
('37', 447, 4, 13, 974921) Swaraj would not drop from the Downing Street but by linking the Congress with the masses through that slender cotton thread.
('37', 447, 4, 14, 975047) He granted that the present franchise could not work because as it stood it was humiliating.
('37', 447, 4, 15, 975140) What had happened in a number of cases was that a few yards of khaddar hired or purchased were kept near the Congress Committee’s offices and the members, while entering the offices in order to participate in committee discussions and registering their votes, put on the khaddar cloth.
('37', 447, 4, 16, 975426) Please do not insult the masses who are dumb.
('37', 447, 4, 17, 975472) They are already sufficiently insulted.

('37', 457, 1, 2, 997377) 195. COMPARISON IN UNTOUCHABILITY
('37', 457, 2, 3, 997411) During my stay in Wardha, I had occasion to visit the untou chable quarters.
('37', 457, 2, 4, 997488) The inmates seemed happy but the awakening that has come into being amongst them has made them dissatisfied with the progress of the campaign against the curse of untouchability.
('37', 457, 2, 5, 997667) The resent the fact that they are still being debarred from the use of temples, wells and public schools in general.
('37', 457, 2, 6, 997784) They cannot, they will not, understand that progress is ‘lame’ and, therefore, tantalizingly slow.
('37', 457, 2, 7, 997883) They can see no reason, there is none, for the insufferable disabilities under which they are labouring.
('37', 457, 2, 8, 997988) Two days after this interesting visit I discovered that in Wardha, thanks to the efforts of Jamnalalji, they were better off than anywhere else.
('37', 457, 2, 9, 998133) They have several public wells open to them.
('37', 457, 2, 10, 998178) They were freely admitted to the Municipal schools.
('37', 457, 2, 11, 998230) As orphans they had the same facilities as the others.
('37', 457, 2, 12, 998285) They had free use of public water taps.
('37', 457, 2, 13, 998325) And a continuous attempt was being made to break down completely the wall of prejudice against them.
('37', 457, 2, 14, 998426) About the same time that I was having experiences of the thou ght current of the untouchable brethren, I had to rehearse to myself the incidents of the untouchability of South Africa.
('37', 457, 2, 15, 998610) I had to do so in view of the Round Table Conference that is deliberating there at present.
('37', 457, 2, 16, 998702) We who are responsible for Indian untouchability are ourselves victims of it in South Africa.
('37', 457, 2, 17, 998796) It is a case over again of ‘the biter bitten’.
('37', 457, 2, 18, 998843) We have sown the wind in India, we are reaping the whirlwind in South Africa.
('37', 457, 2, 19, 998921) The Conference is now sitting to consider whether there is a way out.
('37', 457, 2, 20, 998991) Andrews is making herculean efforts to bring about a happy result.
('37', 457, 2, 21, 999058) He has mobilized the purest forces of South Africa in favour of the cause.
('37', 457, 2, 22, 999133) Let us, however, see the difference between the two untouchabil ities.
('37', 457, 2, 23, 999204) The Indian is withering.
('37', 457, 2, 24, 999229) The axe has been laid at its root.
('37', 457, 2, 25, 999264) Enligh tened public opinion is against it.
('37', 457, 2, 26, 999307) No one whose opinion carries any weight defends it.
('37', 457, 2, 27, 999359) The chains that bind the ‘untouchables’ are daily being broken.
('37', 457, 2, 28, 999423) Law does not countenance it.
('37', 457, 2, 29, 999452) What there is of it is all due to the persistence of custom.
('37', 457, 2, 30, 999513) Customs die hard, they long survive the withdrawal of legal sanction, especially if they are ancient.
('37', 457, 2, 31, 999615) The disappearance of Indian untouchability is now purely a question of time.
('37', 457, 2, 32, 999692) The South African species on the other hand is growing into a hardy tree.
('37', 457, 2, 33, 999766) It is being daily armed with fresh legal sanctions.
('37', 457, 2, 34, 999818) The legal

('37', 458, 1, 2, 999876) disabilities of the Indian untouchables of South Africa have grown with every sitting of the Union Parliament since 1915 in spite of the final settlement of 1914. ('37', 459, 2, 4, 1002371) “HAPPY DESPATCH”?
('37', 459, 2, 5, 1002389) The esteemed correspondent whose letter evoked the article “The Greatest Good of All” 1 (Young India, 9 12 1926) writes:
('37', 459, 3, 6, 1002510) Of the three cases, you have dealt only with the first that of Dr. Blazer and expressed no opinion no the merits of the other two—the Paris case and the Danish law.
('37', 459, 3, 7, 1002675) I and many others of your readers, I am sure, would be grateful if you could enlighten us as to how you would judge these matters also from your own ethical standpoint.
('37', 459, 3, 8, 1002844) The cases referred to are:
('37', 459, 4, 9, 1002871) At about the same time last year I remember I read about the Paris case in which an actress shot and killed her lover at his own importunate request, as he was suffering excruciating pain from a disease from which there was no hope of recovery.
('37', 459, 4, 10, 1003116) The actress was tried for manslaughter, but acquitted on the jury’s verdict that no crime had been committed in view of the circumstances.
('37', 459, 4, 11, 1003255) Though there appears to be no law in France to justify such a verdict, I have read that in Denmark there has been actually a law passed making it no crime for certain authorized persons in cases like the above to put an end to a human life with ‘happy despatch’.
('37', 459, 4, 12, 1003518) In my opinion, such killing, if it is done bona fide, will certainly not count as himsa as understood and defined by me.
('37', 459, 4, 13, 1003639) But I could not take it upon my shoulders to justify such action on the part of a third party, as I would never have sufficient material to judge such a case.
('37', 459, 4, 14, 1003798) The defence will rest solely upon the intention.
('37', 459, 4, 15, 1003847) And since no one but God is the infallible judge of intentions, everyone must act on his own responsibility and take all the consequences.
('37', 459, 4, 16, 1003986) It follows, therefore, that the Danish law cannot be defended.
('37', 459, 4, 17, 1004049) And I should hold it to be most dangerous to justify any act of killing on the ground of the desire of the victim to be killed.
('37', 459, 4, 18, 1004177) There are many cases in which a man may for the moment, being overwhelmed with pain, desire to be killed rather than live in agony.
('37', 459, 4, 19, 1004309) But he would be most grateful upon recovery to know that his wish was not complied with.
('37', 459, 4, 20, 1004398) The better thing would, in my opinion, be boldly to put an end to a life which we may absolutely know to be past saving.
('37', 459, 4, 21, 1004519) Such a case would be that of a comrade on the battle field who has received a fatal wound and who has no possibility of receiving any medical aid.
('37', 459, 4, 22, 1004666) In this case, it will not be his wish that would determine the act of killing but the certain knowledge of a lingering death in utter helplessness and without hope even of loving nursing.
('37', 459, 4, 23, 1004854) For it is assumed that the soldier who ends the agony by
('37', 459, 5, 24, 1004911) 1Vide “The Greatest Good of All”, 9 12 1926.
('37', 460, 0, 1, 1004956) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 461
('37', 460, 1, 2, 1005004) killing is not able even to nurse his wounded comrade.
('37', 460, 1, 3, 1005059) CONTROL OF EVIL THOUGHTS A correspondent sends me an essay in support of the view propounded in these columns in the series of articles “Towards Moral Bankruptcy”.
('37', 460, 1, 4, 1005223) There is nothing new in it, but it contains a quotation from Buddha’s teaching which should help those who are trying to control evil thoughts.
('37', 460, 1, 5, 1005367) Here is the passage:
('37', 460, 2, 6, 1005388) When by reason of a phase of mind, there arise in a brother bad and wrong thoughts associated with appetite, hatred and delusion, then he should divert his mind from that to another phase associated with what is right.
('37', 460, 2, 7, 1005607) If they still arise, then he should study the perils they entail, marking how wrong and depraved such thoughts are and how they ripen into ill.
('37', 460, 2, 8, 1005751) If they still keep on rising, he should ignore them and not let his mind dwell on them.
('37', 460, 2, 9, 1005839) And if they still continue, he must be think him how to allay all these modes and fashions of thoughts.
('37', 460, 2, 10, 1005943) As he does so, these thoughts will pass away and disappear, so that his heart stands firm, is steadfast, is focussed and concentrated.
('37', 460, 2, 11, 1006078) And lastly, if, allay as he may, these thoughts continue to rise, then with his teeth clenched and with his tongue pressed against his palate, he should by sheer force of mind, restrain, coerce and dominate his heart.
('37', 460, 2, 12, 1006296) As he does so these thoughts will pass away and disappear.
('37', 460, 2, 13, 1006355) He will think only such thoughts as he wishes and not those he wishes not to think.
('37', 460, 2, 14, 1006439) Young India, 30 12 1926

('37', 467, 1, 3, 1017990) My ideal is this: A man should remain man and yet should become woman; similarly a woman should remain woman and yet become man.
('37', 467, 1, 4, 1018119) This means that man should cultivate the gentleness and the discrimination of woman; and woman should cast off her timidity and become brave and courageous.
('37', 467, 1, 5, 1018276) It is said that women are jealous, but this does not mean that men are free from this failing or that all women are jealous.

('37', 467, 1, 17, 1019095) I know only one man, and that is Krishna.” On hearing this, the sadhu opened the door, fell at the feet of Mirabai and said, “You have opened my eyes today.
('37', 467, 1, 18, 1019252) I have been saved from an abyss.” * * * Man and woman are characterized by fear as long as both are subject to passions.
('37', 467, 1, 19, 1019373) Draupadi showed as great a strength as Yudhishthira did.
('37', 467, 1, 20, 1019430) Draupadi had five husbands at one time and yet has been called ‘chaste’.
('37', 467, 1, 21, 1019503) This is because in that age, just as a man could marry several wives, a woman (in certain regions) could marry several husbands.
('37', 467, 1, 22, 1019632) The code of marriage changes with time and place.
('37', 467, 1, 23, 1019682) But from another point of view, Draupadi is a symbol of the mind.

('37', 468, 1, 2, 1020192) While in jail, as I read the prayer of Draupadi to Krishna at this time, as given in the Mahabharata, I wept bitterly.

('37', 479, 2, 3, 1046635) AS AT THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, January 1, 1927 DEAR FRIEND 1
('37', 479, 3, 4, 1046694) I was distressed to find that a resolution was brought up before the Congress 2 in connection with yourself.
('37', 479, 3, 5, 1046803) I understood also that the resolution was brought at your desire and instance.
('37', 479, 3, 6, 1046882) When it was first brought to my notice, I told Sardar Sardul Singh that it would be injurious to press the resolution.
('37', 479, 3, 7, 1047001) I told him that even whilst I was ailing in Poona 3 I had studied your Highness’s papers and I was satisfied that yours was not a case for public agitation and that if any relief was to be expected, it was to be had only through proper diplomatic channels which really do not admit of public agitation.
('37', 479, 3, 8, 1047304) I told Sardar Sardul Singh further that it would be wrong for the Congress to be identified with the agitation and it would be harmful to your own cause.
('37', 479, 3, 9, 1047458) Nevertheless, in the absence of Pundit Motilalji and myself, the resolution was brought up before the Subjects Committee which, in my opinion unthinkingly and hastily, adopted it.
('37', 479, 3, 10, 1047638) The following morning I was informed of the event.
('37', 479, 3, 11, 1047689) Pundit Motilalji was equally distressed with me to find that the resolution was passed.
('37', 479, 3, 12, 1047777) And it was only then that I heard that Pundit Motilalji was your legal adviser.
('37', 479, 3, 13, 1047857) As a lawyer of some experience I think that a client does grave injury to his cause who behind the back of his legal adviser adopts means of redressing the wrong which he entrusted to a chosen adviser.
('37', 479, 3, 14, 1048059) I further learn that you were so impatient to be reinstalled that you were paying heavy sums to all sorts of men who at all held out hope of securing relief for you.
('37', 479, 3, 15, 1048225) As a friend and servant of India and therefore of your Highness, I have no hesitation in saying that if you have been paying people in the manner described to me, you are but injuring your cause and your reputation.
('37', 479, 3, 16, 1048441) I think that you could restrain all your friends, however well meaning they may be from carrying on public agitation such as ventilating your case before the Congress, that you should be true to your legal adviser and should do nothing behind his back, and that if you have a good case, you will get relief only through proper and clean diplomatic channels.
('37', 479, 3, 17, 1048799) Lastly, I repeat what I have said to the Sikh friends who, I expect, saw me on

('37', 483, 4, 5, 1054590) VILLENEUVE (VAND) VILLA OLGA, September 26, 1926
('37', 483, 5, 6, 1054639) DEAR FRIEND,
('37', 483, 6, 7, 1054652) I find, at last, an hour for conversing with you—, and, through you, with your Bapu.
('37', 483, 7, 8, 1054737) I am replying to your letter of the end of July, and I return to my regrets that Gandhi could not take part in the conference for Christian Young Men at Helsingfors.
('37', 483, 7, 9, 1054903) Those regrets are accentuated since my meeting with several of these young men and with K. T. Paul.
('37', 483, 8, 10, 1055003) The question is in no way, as you think, one of a fashionable enthusiasm for Gandhiji’s person, or a superficial infatuation for the doctrine of Gandhi.
('37', 483, 8, 11, 1055156) No, there is not even a question of it,—the fact, more unexpected, but indisputable, is that the person, the action, the life and the faith of Gandhi have been the strongest stimulant for European Christianity.
('37', 483, 8, 12, 1055367) Neither you nor Gandhi could have expected it; and it was scarcely the goal for which the Mahatma was searching.
('37', 483, 8, 13, 1055480) But great actions have unexpected repercussions; and often their effect equals or surpasses in importance the effect which had been expected and wished by the man of God.
('37', 483, 8, 14, 1055651) Because, after all, it is not he who acts; it is, by his means, God.
('37', 483, 9, 15, 1055720) The fact is then that Young Christian Europe has seen in Gandhi the purest Christian (without knowing it) of today,—the man who, over and above all the priests and pastors, resumes the direct tradition with the spirit of the Gospel.
('37', 483, 10, 16, 1055953) That he has found himself in possession of immense influence over these young Christians, for interpreting to them their own doctrine, and for showing them the path in an hour of agonizing uncertainties and doubts.
('37', 483, 11, 17, 1056168) Once more, it may be, that Gandhi did not wish this.
('37', 483, 11, 18, 1056221) But once more, another greater than he willed it for him.
('37', 483, 11, 19, 1056279) And he has not the right to escape from it in the future.
('37', 483, 11, 20, 1056337) Because, however imperious may be his Indian task, the human task envelopes it and surpasses it.
('37', 483, 11, 21, 1056434) And whatever may be his personal faith in Hinduism,—the most ardent fire, the most divine of all faith, the eternal is that which feels sin common with all, and not that which differentiates God is in the centre of the Bush.
('37', 483, 11, 22, 1056659) And he who hears Him speak, and repeats what He says, speaks for all.
('37', 483, 12, 23, 1056729) 1 Translated from the French by Mirabehn
('37', 484, 0, 1, 1056770) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 485
('37', 484, 1, 2, 1056818) Now, the Christianity of today is consumed by the anguish of a problem of conscience and faith, that not one of her chief’s or official representatives has the power to solve.
('37', 484, 1, 3, 1056994) I find acute expression of this in the works of a professor of the University of Rome which I have just received.
('37', 484, 1, 4, 1057108) Ubi Christianus?
('37', 484, 1, 5, 1057125) and Dothrina di cristo, by Luigi Trafelli—the author, who is undoubtedly a tortured conscience, starts with the declaration that the “Metanoia” or “evangelical conversion” where the preaching of Jesus begins, is an absolute overthrow and the complete transformation of the values, which, in the normal life of men, are the most appreciated.
('37', 484, 1, 6, 1057466) It is necessary to strip “the old man” and to redress “the new man”, who will not be able to enter into the Kingdom of God, if he does not sacrifice all half duties to the whole duty, and all compromises of the world to the will of perfection.
('37', 484, 1, 7, 1057710) “Be thou then perfect as is thy Father in Heaven.” No concessions to the world.
('37', 484, 1, 8, 1057790) “Leave all and follow Me.”
('37', 484, 2, 9, 1057817) Now, after having examined the perpetual conflicts of this order with the worldly order, and all the “combinations” imagined by the Church and the pseudo believers, for reconciling them, Luigi Trafelli asks himself the mournful question: “Do Christians still exist?” and concludes: “No, they exist no more,”—and he admits himself: “I am not a Christian.”—but adds: “At least, I have not got the hypocrisy to call myself Christian, as do the churches, while betraying the express word of Christ.”
('37', 484, 3, 10, 1058313) This question is made particularly tragic owing to the social crisis, which is passing over Europe,—the world—(and especially the country which is the seat of official catholicism, Italy).
('37', 484, 4, 11, 1058502) At the present hour, the power of the State in Italy has reached a sovereignty which is veritably demoniac.
('37', 484, 4, 12, 1058610) Everything is sacrificed to it, religious conscience is trampled under its feet.
('37', 484, 4, 13, 1058691) The individual soul is annihilated.
('37', 484, 4, 14, 1058727) He who resists the “public will” (translated by one or two leaders who incarnate it) is or will be crushed.
('37', 484, 4, 15, 1058835) A Mussolini, with formidable cynicism, displays this doctrine, accepted by millions of Italians, which will certainly spread before long in Europe and America (above all, in America).
('37', 484, 5, 16, 1059019) Now, what are the guides of religious conscience doing at this hour?
('37', 484, 5, 17, 1059088) They dare not take the responsibility of the nameless sufferings into which they would throw those who ask their advice, by saying to them, “Resist!
('37', 484, 5, 18, 1059237) Be persecuted!” the worst, the most mediocre think of their tranquillity.
('37', 484, 5, 19, 1059311) The best remind themselves of old Tolstoy who was in despair at seeing his disciples persecuted while he could not succeed in getting persecuted himself: because power is too cunning not to treat with care the men who are in broad daylight, and severely the obscure.
('37', 484, 5, 20, 1059578) The result is that all search for and teach compromises—the inner lie; and the soul degrades itself.
('37', 484, 6, 21, 1059679) The young men realize this, they listen for the voice of the gospel which will say to them:
('37', 484, 7, 22, 1059771) “The duty is there—the voice speaks not.
('37', 484, 7, 23, 1059812) They are left—it is for this reason that so many young Christians look towards Gandhi.
('37', 484, 8, 24, 1059899) You say to me, my friend, that it is for me to reply to them.
('37', 485, 0, 1, 1059961) 486 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 485, 1, 2, 1060003) cannot.
('37', 485, 1, 3, 1060011) It is necessary to see me as I am, and not lend to me a faith, thoughts, a mission that I have not got.
('37', 485, 2, 4, 1060115) I am not a Christian, I am not a Gandhist, I am not a believer in a revealed religion.
('37', 485, 2, 5, 1060202) I am a man of the Occident who, in all love and in all sincerity, searches for the truth.
('37', 485, 2, 6, 1060292) That which I strive to teach to myself is for others, it is never to belie one’s own thoughts, never to say that one knows that which one only “believes” or hopes, to say exactly that which one knows,—nothing more,—and, be it that one understands or does not understand, to conserve intact energy and love.
('37', 485, 2, 7, 1060599) The word of the Introduction to The Life of Michael Angelo “See men and life as they are,—and as they are, love them and act .
('37', 485, 3, 8, 1060726) There is my role.

('37', 485, 5, 13, 1061031) We have lately had a visit from a gay American who is making an express tour of all the celebrated men of the globe; five minutes for each one.
('37', 485, 5, 14, 1061175) His name is Buchanan, and he has seen Gandhi at the beginning of the year.

('37', 486, 6, 24, 1064560) APPENDIX III
('37', 486, 7, 25, 1064573) KENYA INDIANS: D. B. DESAI’S LETTER
('37', 486, 8, 26, 1064609) BROACH, December 12, 1926
('37', 486, 9, 27, 1064635) SIR, I think you are by now aware that Kenya (British East Africa) Government has decided to levy an additional tax of one pound on every Indian, as a non native Poll Tax.
('37', 486, 9, 28, 1064807) The Indian Citizens’Association has sent me now the following cable:
('37', 486, 10, 29, 1064876) 1 Vide “Letter to Romain Rolland”, 29 10 1926.
('37', 487, 0, 1, 1064923) 488 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 487, 1, 2, 1064965) “Additional Poll Tax one pound Asiatics only.
('37', 487, 1, 3, 1065011) Move Press, platform, Congress and Government.” From this cablegram, I gather that things have become worse and they ask help of the people of India as well as the Government of India, and I have no doubt that both will readily give assistance to Kenya Indians in the matter.
('37', 487, 1, 4, 1065287) I think it will be of some use if I give you some history as regards this non native Poll Tax.
('37', 487, 1, 5, 1065382) The ordinance for the collection of this non native Poll Tax was passed by the British East Africa Govern ment in the year 1912 to collect from every non native male adult a sum of fifteen rupees per annum from the Ist of January 1913. At this time, i.e., in 1912, there was no Indian Representative—either nominated or elected—on the Kenya Legislative Council; so accor ding to that popular maxim “no taxation without representation”, this non native Poll Tax of fifteen rupees was both bad and unjust as against Indians.
('37', 487, 1, 6, 1065905) Further up to 1920 in Kenya (then British East Africa) the Indian rupee was a current and legal coin, and from 1912 till the day the currency was changed, a rupee there was equivalent to one shilling and four pence; so Indians used to pay every year Rs. 15 equal to 20s Subsequently rupee currency was changed to florin currency, making a florin equal to a rupee (or in other words substituting “florins” wherever the word “rupees” appeared in all the local laws and ordin ances in British East Africa).
('37', 487, 1, 7, 1066409) By this change of currency florins 15 were charged for this non native Poll Tax.
('37', 487, 1, 8, 1066490) In the year 1922, a further change in currency was effected in British East Africa (Kenya) whereby shilling currency was introduced in place of florin currency making two shillings equal to a florin.
('37', 487, 1, 9, 1066690) So under the latter change of currency 30s were charged for this tax, thus making this tax of 30 shillings instead of 20 shillings without any fault of the tax payers.
('37', 487, 1, 10, 1066858) This shows an increase of 50 per cent, which is really, one must admit, unjust.
('37', 487, 2, 11, 1066938) I further think it will be of interest to you to know that in the territories now known as the “Colony and Protectorate of Kenya” there is included a ten miles coastal strip of land which is under the suzerainty of H.H. the Sultan of Zanzibar and for which the Kenya Government, from the day it assumed the administration in that country, is paying an annual rent to H. H. the Sultan of Zanzibar.
('37', 487, 2, 12, 1067335) And under the treaty which has been made by the British Government with the Sultan of Zanzibar, it has been agreed inter alia that no new taxes will be imposed, save and except those enumerated and mentioned in the said treaty upon the residents residing in this ten miles strip and it is understood that the British Government has not got the sanction of H. H. the Sultan of Zanzibar with regard to the levy of this non native Poll Tax.
('37', 487, 3, 13, 1067773) Last month the Kenya Legislative Council has passed the Non Native Poll Tax (amendment) Ordinance whereby the Government will charge every non native male Asiatic 50 instead of 30 shillings stated above.
('37', 487, 3, 14, 1067977) The reason advanced for this and
('37', 488, 0, 1, 1068010) VOL. 37 : 11 NOVEMBER, 1926 1 JANUARY, 1927 489
('37', 488, 1, 2, 1068058) other taxation (of which particulars will be found mentioned below) is to provide for educational facilities to European and Indian children.
('37', 488, 1, 3, 1068200) But the Gover nment of Kenya, it seems to me, has forgotten, when advancing the above reason, that from the beginning till now the Government of Kenya has spent considerably large amounts after European chil dren’s education neglecting and at the cost of Indian children’s edu cation, and the provision was hithertofore made from “General Tax ation”.
('37', 488, 1, 4, 1068551) But now in order to tax the Indian community, it seems to me, the Government has engineered this new device which, in my opinion, is both inequitable and unjust.
('37', 488, 1, 5, 1068713) From the Minority Report which has been submitted by the Hon.
('37', 488, 1, 6, 1068775) Messrs J. B. Pandya and Shamsud Deen, the two nominated Indian members to the Kenya Legislative Council, it appears that the Kenya Government requires £ 52,000 for education purposes and this sum is to be earmarked as follows: Europeans £ 32,000 for 960 children, i.e., about £ 33 17s per head Indians £ 20,000 for 2,318 children, i.e., about £ 812s per head So from this one could easily understand how Indian education in Kenya is neglected.
('37', 488, 1, 7, 1069219) Over and above the number of children mentioned above there are 2,547 Indian children without any means of education.
('37', 488, 1, 8, 1069337) Further, I think, it will not be out of place here to mention to you that school going children pay 2s, 4s and 8s per month according to the standard in which they study, which will also mean that Indian children are contributing much more than their European brothers and sisters and this fact the Government of Kenya has omitted to take into its consideration.
('37', 488, 1, 9, 1069700) As stated in the Majority Report (which is signed by the Colonial Secretary to the Government of Kenya as one of the Members of the Committee), which is submitted to the Kenya Government (and of which report the Governor has spoken in very high terms) and which is passed by the Kenya Legislative Council, the said amount of £ 52,000 has been raised in the following way: Spirits £ 25,000; Wines £ 7,000; Champagnes £ 500; Male domestic servants £ 7,000 (from Europeans only) and Asiatic Poll Tax £ 12,000. It is alleged and assumed in the said Majority Report that for the first three items which are to produce £ 32,500 in taxation, £ 24,500 will be contributed by the Europeans and the rest by the Indians.
('37', 488, 1, 10, 1070410) But as the Kenya Government keeps no record to show the proportion, it will be unwise to arrive at any assumption.
('37', 488, 1, 11, 1070525) Barring this £ 32,500 there remains £19,000 in the new taxation which are divided between the Europeans and the Indians; the former contribute £ 7,000 and the latter £12,000. The domestic servants’ tax which is mentioned in the above paragraph is to be payable “at the rate of two shillings per mensem on every male domestic servant above the apparent age of sixteen and in excess of two servants per household” which will mean that there will be many families which will not be burdened with this tax,
('37', 489, 0, 1, 1071028) 490 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('37', 489, 1, 2, 1071070) which is not an individual tax, while in the case of the additional Asiatic Poll Tax every male adult Asiatic will have to pay 20s extra.
('37', 489, 1, 3, 1071208) Here too there is an open injustice.
('37', 489, 1, 4, 1071245) One of the members who has signed the said Majority Report has stated during the debate in the Kenya Legislative Council, “With regard to the Poll Tax, this was especially put in to meet the requirements of the Indian community, as it was felt that the Indian community did not spend money in the country on luxuries like Europeans did, but sent it out of the country.” From the above statement one naturally gathers the prejudices which are working in the matter of levying of this new tax.
('37', 489, 1, 5, 1071737) The only motive for the new additional one pound poll tax, to my mind, is to harass the law abiding Indian citizens of Kenya by the Kenya Government which is in the hands of the Kenya white settlers practically speaking.
('37', 489, 1, 6, 1071958) On behalf of the Kenya Indians I have to request you to take this matter up and do the needful justice to this subject as occasions require.
('37', 489, 1, 7, 1072099) Your advice to Kenya Indians will be appreciated.
('37', 489, 1, 8, 1072149) I may in the end mention that if the people in India and the Government of India will not take steps to cause this new additional tax to be re moved, the Kenya Government will start collecting it from the Ist January, 1927 and if it is once collected it will be very difficult, as I understand it, to get it removed.
('37', 489, 1, 9, 1072466) I think the Gauhati Congress should take this matter up.
('37', 489, 2, 10, 1072523) Yours, etc.,
('37', 489, 3, 11, 1072536) D.B. DESAI Young India, 23 12 1926
